publication: Y. C. Park, Y. J. Shinn, Y. S. Lee and B. I. Choi, “Estimation of CO2 Storage Capacity in a Depleted Gas Field on the Korean Continental Shelf.,” in 14th International Conference on Greenhouse Gas Control Technologies, GHGT-14., Melbourne, Australia, 2018.
project_history: Donghae-1 gas field is located in the in southern Ulleung basin in the East Sea (58km from Ulsan coast). Production between 2004 and end-2016 the field has produced 169 BCF gas and 3.2 MMbbl ultra-light crude. Several adjacent structures also contain small volumes of natural gas. Donghae-2 (50.8 BCF recoverable reserves) started production in 2015. Previous studies appear to over-estimate storage resource for the Donghae-1 field.
development_plan: End of field life unknown but is considered to be 'soon' (2018). Static geological model built using publicly-available data (OGIP in model 10-20% lower than value confirmed by KNOC - operator). Simulation using CMG-GEM. GWC placed at 2489m. Three injection scenarios modeled: 1) 2 injection wells into depleted gas reservoir. 2) 2 wells into undepleted gas reservoir. 3) 3 injection wells into depleted gas reservoir with 1 brine production well. Storage efficiency in Scenario 2 closed system = 1%. Scenario 3: brine production well too proximal to injection well causing early breakthrough.
containment_summary: No discussion.
assessment_notes: Scenario 1 (2 injection wells/depleted reservoir: 20.9 Mt. Scenario 2 (2 injection wells, undepleted reservoir): 3.6 Mt. Scenario 3 (3 injection wells / 1 brine production well): 24.3 Mt. Resource located in same area (different SRMS maturity) as the Ulleung Basin: SW Margin site.
author: SB
source_of_analogue: Dynamic simulation

publication: G. Lee, B. Lee, H.-J. Kim, K. Lee and M. Park, “The geological CO2 storage capacity of the Jeju Basin, offshore southern Korea, estimated using the storage efficiency.,” International Journal of Greenhouse Gas Control, pp. 22-29, 2014.
project_history: Analysis of storage resource in the non-marine sediments of the Jeju Basin, in the northern part of the East China Sea shelf basin to the south of the Korean Peninsula. More than 5000m of Late Cretaceous and younger sediments reported to be present in Jeju basin. Evaluation based on seismic (8200m)and well logs (8 wells). 14 structural traps previously identified in Jeju Basin (Lee et al. 2012). Lee et al 2014 study assumes open system.
development_plan: None available. Open system assumed for storage efficiency parameters.
containment_summary: No information provided. Assumption that shallow marine sediments sitting above rift-related non-marine section may form a regional seal.
assessment_notes: Deterministic approach for resource evaluation using published storage efficiency parameters and a very simplistic sub-division of subsurface section. Resource calculations derived from a series of horizontal layers which cut-across geology and use average values for input into volumetric analyses. NOTE: Kim et al (2014) quotes a EOR-related storage resource of 95,101Mt for the Jeju basin (value taken from   Egawa et al 2009) but in an earlier paper (Kim et al 2013 gives the same value for saline aquifer storage (value taken from MEST 2008 (in Korean)). Care should be taken when using these figures.
author: SB
source_of_analogue: Volumetric analysis based on calculation of E(saline) using NETL (2010) approach. Inputs derived from seismic and well log data. E(saline) parameter values calculated for local conditions: min: 0.2%; mid: 2%, max: 8%

publication: A.-R. Kim, G.-C. Cho and T.-H. Kwon, “Site characterization and geotechnical aspects on geological storage of CO2 in Korea,” Geosciences Journal, vol. 18, no. 2, pp. 167-179, 2014.
project_history: The Pohang Basin was evaluated for a pilot study in South Korea (the Yeong-Il Bay site; Park et al. 2016)  where simulation indicated injection of up to 40,000t. Kim et al 2013 & 2014 published a suggested basin-level 38 Mt based on evaluation by MEST 2008 (in Korean).
containment_summary: None provided. Note should be made of the Pohang City 5.4 magnitude earthquake in November 2017 which caused cessation of all fluid injection activities (CO2 and geothermal), although some subsequent publications infer the earthquake was caused by geothermal energy activities.
assessment_notes: Resource estimation assigned to Undiscovered: Basin Play but placed in Inaccessible category due to lack of CCS-Specific regulatory system in S Korea. The lack of accessible supporting data/information suggests the resource estimate should be considered 'low confidence'.
author: SB
source_of_analogue: None available.

publication: C. Huh, S. Kang, M. Park, K. Lee, Y. Park, D. Min and J. Lee, “Latest CO2 Transport, Storage and Monitoring R&D Progress in Republic of Korea: Offshore Geologic Storage,” Energy Procedia, pp. 6520-6526, 2013.
project_history: Very high level estimation of potential storage resource. The Ulleung Basin in the East Sea contains >11km Late Oligocene and younger predominantly marine sediments. Published studies focus on the SW Margin of the basin. The Ulleung Basin is the only active hydrocarbon-producing (mainly gas and light condensate) basin in S Korea. Available data: 8500km 2D, 2400 sqkm 3D. 23 wells. Further data (seismic/wells) collection planned 2009-2018. Two distinct regions: Gorae structure and Dolgorae structure.
containment_summary: No discussion. 1 commercial producing field and other smaller gas accumulations indicate a working seal is present in part of basin.
assessment_notes: Very high level theoretical estimate of resource. No details on inputs into volumetric calculation provided. Storage resource for Donghae-1 Gas field resource subtracted to avoid double accounting.
author: SB
source_of_analogue: Volumetric analysis based on calculation of E(saline) using NETL (2010) approach (P10:2.2%, P50: 5.5%, P90: 13.7%). Inputs derived from seismic and well log data.

publication: British Geological Survey. 2008. A Regional Assessment of the Potential for the CO2 Storage in the Indian Subcontinent. IEAGHG.
project_history: Research study undertaken by the British Geological Survey, comparing the CO2 sources and sinks in the Indian subcontinent to screen for CCS focus areas.
containment_summary: Structural/stratigraphic trapping within depleted hydrocarbon fields.
assessment_notes: Noted that an estimated 10-20 MMbbls of oil may lie in the Cauvery Basin, and a further 100MMbbls of oil in the Mannar Basin, however no evaluation could be produced at the time of assessment.
author: AJ

publication: HyNet North West, 2020, HyNet CCUS Pre-Feed Key Knowledge Deliverable, WP1: Full Chain Basis of Design
project_history:
This site was approved for Track 1 cluster funding by the UK Government. The project known as Hynet includes the Hamilton, Hamilton North and Lennox fields. The project is  now in the Pre-feed stage and agreement in principles with DESNZ (Department for Energy Security and Net Zero) UK. Hynet Northwest is a project to produce, transport and store low carbon hydrogen with a component to store CO2 from the industrial sources in the North west regions. ENI are the partner responsible for transport and storage of CO2. Timeline is as follows: • Pre-FEED: April 2019 to April 2020_x000D_
• FEED: April 2020 to April 2022_x000D_
• Onshore Pipeline Consent Determination (DCO): April 2022_x000D_
• Offshore Storage License: April 2022_x000D_
• Financial Investment Decision (FID): June 2022_x000D_
• Construction and Commissioning: June 2022 to June 2024_x000D_
• Capture Operations (Fertiliser Plant): June 2024 onwards_x000D_
• Capture Operations (Refinery): December 2024 onwards_x000D_
• Capture Operations (Hydrogen Production): June 2025 onwards
development_plan: Hynet will capture Co2 from a number of sources: Industrial and Hydrogen. Injection is planned in the gas phase and will turn to liquid phase when the reservoir pressures increase to the point that liquid phase is needed. A baseline configuration (gas phase) will include a newbuild pipeline capable of transporting up to 10MtCO2/yr to a cumulative storage of 70 Mt . Additional scenarios were set out (high, med &  Low) with cumulative storage of 193, 128 and 28.7 MtCo2 respectively. Higher case assumes both Lennox and Hamilton East will be needed to increase the capacity. The baseline for Hamilton is reported in the CSRC.
containment_summary:
There is a high level of confidence that over 120Mt of CO2 can be_x000D_
_x000D_
contained within the Ormskirk Sandstone in the Hamilton structure_x000D_
_x000D_
• 1000 years after injection has ceased the CO2 plume is still_x000D_
_x000D_
contained within the Hamilton structure and the defined storage_x000D_
_x000D_
complex._x000D_
_x000D_
• The primary seal is provided by a 700m sequence of mudstones and_x000D_
_x000D_
halites of the Mercia Mudstone Group, specifically the Rossall Halite._x000D_
_x000D_
• Underlying the Sherwood Sandstone is approximately [1000ft] of the_x000D_
_x000D_
tight St Bees Sandstone which prevented aquifer ingress during_x000D_
_x000D_
hydrocarbon operations. The St Bees Sandstone is likely to be_x000D_
_x000D_
virtually impermeable to CO2 and provide a very effective_x000D_
_x000D_
containment feature at the floor of the store._x000D_
_x000D_
• Hamilton has minimal risk of caprock or fault failure for the modelled_x000D_
_x000D_
stress conditions, reservoir and overburden properties and fault_x000D_
_x000D_
properties.
assessment_notes: The source is a pre-feed document that outlines the full chain basis of design. Storage volumes are taken from the scenarios set out for the CO2 capture and storage phase of the project.
author: KE
source_of_analogue: Storage efficiency was reported from a range of simulation sensitivity runs

publication: Energy Technologies Institute (ETI). 2015. “DECC Storage Appraisal: Prospect Summary Sheets.”
project_history: Cycle 4 update: This site sits in the licence block CS010 Awarded to Spirit Energy on 01/07/2023. No further details have been published on any plans. This site was assessed as Site No 10 in a portfolio of 20 which were documented as posters in the source study.  Further details are presented in the UK CO2Stored database at www.co2stored.co.uk.
development_plan: The development plan is assumed to commence with a normally unmanned installation comprising a jacket and topsides with 5 deviated wells each injecting 1Mt/yr totalling 100Mt over 20 years.  CO2 would be delivered through a new 20" pipeline from point of Ayr with a throughput capacity of 10Mt/yr.  Facilities will be controlled from the beach with the NUI providing its own power and controls.  Monitoring will include downhole pressure and DTS
containment_summary: An overburden evaluation was reported both above and adjacent to the Ormskirk Sandstone to identify secondary containment horizons and potential migration pathways out of the storage complex.  The reservoir is overlain by almost 1000m of Mercia mudstones and evaporites forming an excellent and continuous caprock.  Key containment risk is associated with legacy wells although considered to be low.
assessment_notes: Source Poster contains development plan summary and cost estimate for the initial phase of a large project.  Calculation of storable volumes was based upon replacement of produced gas back to initial pressure and evaluated using a simple dynamic model. Probabilistic storable quantities were not reported.
author: KE
source_of_analogue: Calculated by material balance with voidage replacement back to initial pressure

publication: Energy Technologies Institute (ETI). 2015. “DECC Storage Appraisal: Prospect Summary Sheets.”
project_history: Cycle 4 update: This site sits in the licence block CS010 Awarded to Spirit Energy on 01/07/2023. No further details have been published on any plans. This site was assessed as Site No 3 in a portfolio of 20 which were documented as posters in the source study.  Further details are presented in the UK CO2Stored database at www.co2stored.co.uk.
development_plan: The development plan is assumed to commence with a normally unmanned installation comprising a jacket and topsides with 5 deviated wells each injecting 1Mt/yr totalling 100Mt over 20 years.  CO2 would be delivered through a new 20" pipeline from point of Ayr with a throughput capacity of 10Mt/yr.  Facilities will be controlled from the beach with the NUI providing its own power and controls.  Monitoring will include downhole pressure and DTS.  Full development would incorporate 9 new platforms with 43 wells in total
containment_summary: An overburden evaluation was reported both above and adjacent to the Ormskirk Sandstone to identify secondary containment horizons and potential migration pathways out of the storage complex.  Field data and published literature show a broad dome horst structure with a create at 914m fault bounded on the western margin. Extensional faults cut the reservoir .  The reservoir is overlain by almost 1000m of Mercia mudstones and evaporites forming an excellent and continuous caprock.  Key containment risk is associated with legacy wells.
assessment_notes: Source Poster contains development plan summary and cost estimate for the initial phase of a large project.  Calculation of storable volumes was based upon replacement of produced gas back to initial pressure and evaluated using a simple dynamic model.  Fracture pressure was quoted as 3265PSIG and report noted initial injectivity would be in gas phase.  Probabilistic storable quantities were not reported.
author: KE
source_of_analogue: Calculated by material balance with voidage replacement back to initial pressure

publication: Pale Blue Dot, 2021,Acorn CCS Project D08 Operations and Maintenance Philosophy ACCS-X-00-PB-PM-KK-000P
project_history: This site sits in CS003 Licence block awarded 01/01/2018 to Pale Blue Dot. In 2023 Acorn received licences for Acorn East and East Mey - CS011 and CS012 respectively. Acorn was awarded Track 2 cluster funding in 2023. At 2021 the project was entering the Define phase
development_plan: The development plan envisaged in the primary source was a four well development from a subsea template.  A single brine production well was considered to assist with pressure management.  Injection rates of 5Mt/yr were assumed.  CO2 is sourced from the St Fergus gas terminal complex with an initial capture of 300ktCO2/yr. Project Duration was set to 35 years.  CO2 will be injected in dense phase through the Goldeneye pipeline. Once phase 1 infrastructure is established, Phase 2 will lead to drilling additional wells to inject 1.5-2.0Mt/yr in Acorn South and central  (CS011 and CS003 respectively). This development plan is under further evolution and further details have not yet been available in the public domain at cycle 4.
containment_summary: The primary seal is provided by the marls and mudstones of the Rodby Formation, which is a proven seal for many hydrocarbon fields in the area. Over the Acorn storage site it is about 90-100m thick and in the ETI SSAP work it was mapped across the fairway. The base seal is provided by the Valhall Formation, which consists of shales and marls.
assessment_notes: The primary source is a detailed storage development plan which included an assessment against a prototype SRMS system.  A 35 year injection duration was modelled.  Low Case Estimate is based upon a partial development case limited to 64Mt (Scenario 2 P68 in source).  Mid estimate is based upon low simulation case (P71in source  run SR18) , High estimate is the base case from the published development plan (P73 in source). All estimates exclude any potential contribution from pore space use within the Goldeneye structure.  Area is licensed and resources assigned to the Development on hold category pending update of revised development currently being devised.
author: KE
source_of_analogue: Storage efficiency was reported from a range of simulation sensitivity runs

publication: Energy Technologies Institute (ETI). 2015. “DECC Storage Appraisal: Prospect Summary Sheets.”
project_history: There is no project currently planned at the site and reported in the public domain.  The site has been the subject of a small number of research studies including the primary source which derived from a study commissioned by the Up Energy Technology Institute in 2015
development_plan: The development plan envisaged in the primary source was a five well development from a small unmanned platform.  No brine production or pressure management was designed.  Injection rates of 5Mt/yr were assumed.  No CO2 source is specified, but it was assumed that the CO2 supply was by new pipeline from the Humberside area.  CO2 will initially be injected in gas phase due to the very low depletion pressure expected.
containment_summary: The Barque field has been subjected to an overburden and containment review which has been reported in the source document. The structured are overlain by thick Zechstein evaporites between 152 and 1219m thick which provide an excellent seal.  Key containment risk is associated with legacy wells, although this is considered to be low.
assessment_notes: Source Poster contains development plan summary and cost estimate for the initial phase of a large project.  Calculation of storable volumes was based upon the replacement method.  Probabilistic storable quantities were not reported.
author: AJ
source_of_analogue: Storable quantities estimated using replacement methodology

publication: Energy Technologies Institute (ETI). 2015. “DECC Storage Appraisal: Prospect Summary Sheets.”
project_history: This site was assessed as Site No 8 in a portfolio of 20 which were documented as posters in the source study.  Further details are presented in the UK CO2Stored database at www.co2stored.co.uk.
development_plan: The source reports a proposed subsea development in the vicinity of the Bruce platform (assumed removed) with 5 deviated wells each injecting 1Mt/yr.  Assumed to be supplied by the re-use of the MGS pipeline system plus a new 148km 20" extension pipeline to Bruce.  Assumed that power and control will be from an existing neighbouring platform. Monitoring will be via downhole pressure gauges and DTS.  Project uses  2 subsea manifolds with 9 wells each.
containment_summary: An overburden evaluation was reported both above and adjacent to the Ormskirk Sandstone to identify secondary containment horizons and potential migration pathways out of the storage complex.  Field data and published literature show three main reservoir blocks with a create at 3320m.  The field is faulted with a major structure controlling the west flank. Sufficient caprock seal is provided by the Heather formation which has enabled trapping of gas condensate and is expected to perform well for CO2 containment.  Key containment risk is associated with legacy wells.
assessment_notes: Source Poster contains development plan summary and cost estimate for the initial phase of a large project.  Calculation of storable volumes was based upon replacement of produced gas back to initial pressure and evaluated using a simple material balance model.   Probabilistic storable quantities were not reported.

publication: BP Exploration Operating Company Limited, 2022, Multi-Store Development Philosophy Key Knowledge Document, NS051-SS-PHI-000-00010
project_history: Cycle 4 update: This site sits within site CS007 of the UK NSTA license round for CO2 sites in 2023. BP and Equinor are the license holders and was awarded on 01/05/2022. Bunter Closure 36 has been identified as a structure suitable for storing CO2  due to proximity to Endurance. The site was assessed in  Key Knowledge Document (NS051-SS-PHI-000-00010) was generated as part of the pre-FEED project stage for Northern Endurance Partnership and Net Zero Teesside for application of licence CS006 & CS007. It is proposed to use Bunter Closure 36 as an alternative expansion store to increase injection rates in Endurance and remove brine.
development_plan: The alternative expansion strategy for Endurance in order to achieve Phase 2 injection rates (10 MTPA average), is to inject into other nearby Bunter stores – the Bunter Closures  36, 37, 39 and 40. This is to remove the brine from Endurance and retain safe reservoir pressure.
containment_summary:
There is a high level of confidence that over 280Mt of CO2 can be contained within the Bunter 36 structure. 1000 years after injection has ceased the CO2 plume is contained within the Bunter 36 structural closure and easily within the defined storage complex._x000D_
• The overlying Rot Halite formation forms the primary seal is 60m thick over the structure. Its' mobile nature means that it is resilient to fracturing and almost totally impermeable_x000D_
• There are multiple further secondary sealing intervals within the overlying Haisborough group which further secure the integrity of the site._x000D_
• Underlying the Bunter Sandstone is approximately 1000ft of Bunter Shale which comprises a series of shales and siltstones.
assessment_notes: Revised volumes have been assessed in in  Key Knowledge Document (NS051-SS-PHI-000-00010). Bunter closure 36 is expected to be analogous to Endurance. P50 Volumetrics indicate volume with brine pressure management of 271 MT and without brine pressure management of 74 MT. The revised volume of 74 MT is taken as P50 estimate to provide the more realistic volume based on the Endurance development plan.
author: KE
source_of_analogue: Storage efficiency was reported from a range of simulation sensitivity runs

project_history: Cycle 4 update: This site sits within site CS006 of the UK NSTA license round for CO2 sites in 2023. BP and Equinor are the license holders and was awarded on 01/05/2022. Bunter Closure 36 has been identified as a structure suitable for storing CO2  due to proximity to Endurance. The site was assessed in  Key Knowledge Document (NS051-SS-PHI-000-00010) was generated as part of the pre-FEED project stage for Northern Endurance Partnership and Net Zero Teesside for application of licence CS006 & CS007. It is proposed to use Bunter Closure 40 as an alternative expansion store to increase injection rates in Endurance and remove brine.
development_plan: The alternative expansion strategy for Endurance in order to achieve Phase 2 injection rates (10 MTPA average), is to inject into other nearby Bunter stores – the Bunter Closures  36, 37, 39 and 40. This is to remove the brine from Endurance and retain safe reservoir pressure.
containment_summary: An overburden evaluation is reported.  The site is a simple 4 way dip closure. Primary seal is over 700m of Triassic mudstones and evaporites.  Key containment risk is associated with legacy wells.
assessment_notes: Revised volumes have been assessed in in  Key Knowledge Document (NS051-SS-PHI-000-00010). Bunter closure 40 lacks data to demonstrate injectivity and have slightly different reservoir properties from Endurance. P50 Volumetrics indicate volume with brine pressure management of 93 MT and without brine pressure management of 25 MT. The revised volume of 25 MT is taken as P50 estimate to provide the more realistic volume based on the Endurance development plan.

publication: Energy Technologies Institute (ETI). 2015. “DECC Storage Appraisal: Prospect Summary Sheets.”
project_history: Cycle 4 update: This site sits within site CS009 of the UK NSTA license round for CO2 sites in 2023. Perenco are the license holders. License awarded 01/07/2023. The adjacent Lemen site is designated a major reservoir the  Poseidon Project. Perenco appear to assess the capacity of both the Lemen and Bunter 9 together. This site was assessed as Site No 1 in a portfolio of 20 which were documented as posters in the Energy Technologies Institute (ETI). 2015. “DECC Storage Appraisal: Prospect Summary Sheets.” study.  Further details are presented in the UK CO2Stored database at www.co2stored.co.uk.
development_plan: This site is part of the Poseidon Project. Perenco UK and the partner Carbon Catalyst Ltd will operate the site. The project is planned to decarbonise the East Anglia, Greater London and Southeast England. Projected to be online by 2029 with initial injection rates of around 1.5 Mtpa, rising to 10Mtpa by 2030, peaking at 40 Mtpa over a 40 year period. Information relating to the development plan is sourced from the Poseidon Project website
containment_summary: An overburden evaluation is reported.  Primary seal is over 800m of Triassic mudstones and evaporites.  Key containment risk is associated with legacy wells.
assessment_notes: At cycle 4 there is limited data to update any assessment quantities. Development plans and injection rates are found on the Poseidon Project Website state that  ultimate storage capacity of the Lemen field including the bunter closure 9 aquifer is 1000 Mt. Methodology to define this is not documented in literature. It is assumed that capacity studies have been performed by the license holder. Due to high uncertainty of actual volumes, this site remains unchanged with respect to volume until further assessment become available in the development plans.
author: KE
source_of_analogue: Calculated by volumetric method.

publication: ACT Acorn, 2019, D20 Final Report, 10196ACTC-Rep-35-01
project_history: This site sits in CS012 Licence block awarded 01/07/2023 to Pale Blue Dot and Shell. In 2023 Acorn received licences for Acorn East and East Mey. Acorn was awarded Track 2 cluster funding in 2023. At 2021 the project was entering the Define phase
development_plan: A detailed development plan was not available in the public domain for cycle 4, however, East Mey is planned as an expansion store for Acorn. No detailed development plan was available in the public domain at Cycle 4
containment_summary: The site has a combined structural and residual trapping system.  Secure vertical containment is provided by the already extensive Lista Shales which are a proven seal for multiple Palaeocene hydrocarbon fields in the Central North Sea, including the Balmoral, MacCulloch, Brenda and Donan fields
assessment_notes: The model was run against three CO2 supply profiles.  These do not test the ultimate resource potential.  In Annex 2 of the Storage development plan, continued injection to over 500Mt was achieved in the model whilst retaining vertical and lateral integrity.  No probabilistic evaluation was conducted
author: KE

publication: BP Exploration Operating Company Limited, 2022, Endurance Storage Development Plan, Key Knowledge Document, NS051-SS-REP-000-00010
project_history:
The site has been the subject of extensive studies by The Net Zero Teesside (NZT) project in association with the Northern Endurance Partnership_x000D_
project (NEP) intend to facilitate decarbonisation of the Humber and Teesside industrial_x000D_
clusters during the mid-2020s. The project will include pipelines from the Humber and Teesside region to the Endurance site. The project meets the Government plan for having at least 2 clusters storing up to 10Mtpa by 2030. The Hewett gas field was a contender for this project, however Endurance proved to be a significantly better option. First CO2 capture is planned for 2026.
development_plan: Phase 1 plan include 5 subsea wells to deliver a volume of 4 Mtpa over 25 years with peak injection rates of 5.6 Mtpa. Phase 2 plans to ramp up to 10 Mtpa with the addition of 6 Co2 injectors and 8 brine producers. The aim is to produce up to 160,000 bwpd of brine. Additional store sites are considered since the 450 Mt is not sufficient for the combined capacity of Humber and Teesside. The Bunter closures 36, 37, 39, and 40 are assessed for the expansion store.
containment_summary: Containment has been considered in CO2Stored and reported in FEED deliverables published by UK Government. Endurance is a 4 way dip closure approx. 22 km long and 8 km wide. 3 wells penetrate the structure. Overburden consists of several sequences of shales and Halite with a thickness of around 100m. There is no evidence of faulting in the Bunter Aquifer of Endurance although they do exist in the overburden.
assessment_notes:
According to the Northern Endurance Partnership, Endurance has the capacity to store 450 Mt. If additional sites are included surrounding Endurance then the capacity can increase to 1 billion tonnes (https://www.netzeroteesside.co.uk/northern-endurance-partnership/). Volumes in this assessment are provided by the source document which provides a detailed analysis and simulation. Core data was acquired to assess the reservoir properties. The maximum CO2 storage capacity of
Endurance is estimated to be circa 450 MT (25 years at 18 Mtpa or 30 years at 15 Mtpa). Phase 1 is documented as having 100Mt documented for development and therefore placed as justified for development. The remaining resources are placed in the contingent classes. corresponding to a static CO2 storage efficiency of 15%)
author: KE
source_of_analogue: Detailed reservoir assessment provided by source document which used core data and dynamic simulations to assess the site.

publication: Energy Technologies Institute ETI. 2015. “DECC Storage Appraisal: WP5B - Forties 5 Site 1 Storage Development Plan 10113ETIS-Rep-18-00.”
project_history: There is no project currently planned at the site and reported in the public domain.  The site has been the subject of a small number of research studies including the primary source which derived from a study commissioned by the UK Energy Technology Institute in 2015
development_plan: The development plan envisaged in the primary source was a two phase development comprising a NUI platform in the southern part of the storage site followed some 10 years later by a subsea tie back to the north.  The injection plan uses a 9 well development and injection occurs over 40 years  at a rate which rises from 6Mt/yr to 8Mt/yr.
containment_summary:
The primary seal is provided by the mudstones of the Sele Formation which is 90 – 100m thick over the site._x000D_
_x000D_
• There is a high degree of confidence that over 300Mt of CO2 can be contained within the Forties Sandstone in Site 1 of the Forties 5 aquifer unit._x000D_
_x000D_
• 1000 years after the cessation of injection the CO2 plume is still contained within the Storage Complex._x000D_
_x000D_
• The initial Storage Complex boundary could be adjusted in subsequent studies to provide additional certainty around containment within the planned lease area._x000D_
_x000D_
• Underlying the Forties Sandstone are the claystones and mudstones of the Lista Formation._x000D_
_x000D_
• Site 1 also encompasses the Huntington and Everest hydrocarbon fields provide secondary containment._x000D_
_x000D_
• The nature and continuity of the high and low permeability intervals are likely to have a significant influence on the evolution of the CO2 plume.
assessment_notes: The primary source is a detailed storage development plan which included an assessment against a prototype SRMS system.  A 40 year injection duration was modelled, but further storage resource is available.  Low estimate is based upon P90 probabilistic evaluation calibrated to simulation work, Mid estimate is the base case from the development plan and the high estimate comes from an high permeability scenario with a 70 year injection duration.
author: AJ
source_of_analogue: Storage efficiency was reported from a range of simulation sensitivity runs

publication: Energy Technologies Institute (ETI). 2015. “DECC Storage Appraisal: Strategic UK CO2 Storage Appraisal - Project - Addendum.”
project_history: There is no project currently planned at the site and reported in the public domain.  The site is included in the CO2stored database and reported briefly in the Strategic UK CO2 Storage Appraisal Project - Addendum
development_plan: Borda, et al.,2017 Provide a simulation for the Forties and Nelson field to understand how capacity can be increased with a brine producers. The simulations used 8 injection wells and 5 production wells aimed at producing 2.2 MMtones/year over a 40 year period. Optimisation was preformed to assess pressure build up. Borda, E.S., Govindan, R., Elahi, N., Korre, A., Durucan, S., 2017, The development of dynamic CO2 injection strategy for the depleted Forties and Nelson oilfield using regression-based multi-objective programming, Energy Procedia, 114, 3335-3342
containment_summary: Containment has been considered in CO2Stored. Borda et al., 2017 cite that the reservoir is capped by the Charlie Shale. The depositional environment of a submarine fan created some complex heterogeneities and potential barriers to CO2 movement.
assessment_notes: Source document reports only P50 capacity estimate,  Normal CO2Stored methodologies apply (Volumetric method for saline aquifers and replacement methods for oil and gas fields).  The source documentation contains no further details, but these can be accessed at www.co2stored.co.uk.A dynamic simulation  by Borda et al 2017 (see development plan for citation) is reported in the literature however the absolute volumes are not specified for each site and therefore the source volume is referenced as the storable quantities. The dynamic simulation models the Forties and Nelson Field for simultaneous injection of CO2 and brine production . Storage increased by 125% with brine production .
author: KE
source_of_analogue: Assumed Oil and gas replacement

publication: Shell UK. 2015. “Peterhead CCS Project - Storage Development Plan.”
project_history: The report documents a detailed FEED programme for a specific Co2 storage development at the Goldeneye depleted gas field.  The development plan was originally designed to support emissions reduction from the Longannet coal power plant,, but was subsequently revised to support a CCS project from the Peterhead power plant.  In 2015 the project was abandoned after the UK Government withdrew significant capital funding support.  The gas field is now undergoing decommissioning.
development_plan: Specific development plan is considered in detail.  This involved re-using the existing wells, platform and pipeline.  The details are documented within the source document.  The project was designed to inject between 10 and 20Mt at a rate of 1Mt per year.
containment_summary: Containment has been considered in detail and verified by independent third party technical review.  The site represents one of the best characterised CO2 storage sites in the world.
assessment_notes: The Source document reports a range of CO2 storage resource estimates including a range which has been delivered from a series of multiple deterministic realisations and simulations runs.  Area is licensed and resources assigned to the Development on hold category pending update of revised development currently being devised.
author: KE
source_of_analogue: Full detailed simulation model results presented

storage_unit_type: Open, no identified structural/ stratigraphic confinement
publication: Energy Technologies Institute (ETI). 2015. “DECC Storage Appraisal: Prospect Summary Sheets.”
project_history: This site was assessed as Site No 11 in a portfolio of 20 which were documented as posters in the source study.  Further details are presented in the UK CO2Stored database at www.co2stored.co.uk.
development_plan: The development plan is assumed to commence with a new subsea installation in the vicinity of the Miller field and 5 deviated wells each injecting 1Mt/yr. CO2 would be delivered by the reuse of the MGS pipeline with power and controls supplied from an existing neighbouring platform.   Monitoring will include downhole pressure and DTS.  Full development would incorporate 10 drill centres each with 5 wells connected by 10km infield flowlines
containment_summary: An overburden evaluation is reported.  The site is a large extensive deep sea clastic system with some elements of a combined stratigraphic and structural closure in places.   Eocene Horda mudstones.  Containment risk is elevated due to the presence of extensive polygonal faulting .  Key containment risk is associated with legacy well penetrations of which there are a very large number, however well density is relatively low
assessment_notes: Source Poster contains development plan summary and cost estimate for the initial phase of a large project.  Calculation of storable volumes was based upon the volumetric method/  Probabilistic storable quantities were not reported.
author: AJ
source_of_analogue: Calculated by volumetric method using storage efficiency.

publication: Energy Technologies Institute (ETI). 2015. “DECC Storage Appraisal: Prospect Summary Sheets.”
project_history: This site was assessed as Site No 28 in a portfolio of 20 which were documented as posters in the source study.  Further details are presented in the UK CO2Stored database at www.co2stored.co.uk.
development_plan: The development plan is assumed to commence with a new subsea installation with four deviated subsea wells with power and control supplied by a nearby existing facility.  CO2 delivered through reuse of the MGS pipeline.
containment_summary: An overburden evaluation is reported.  Primary seal is the T60 mudstone, a proven seal for hydrocarbons, but with the complexity of sand injection features.    Legacy wells present a moderate containment risk.
assessment_notes: Source Poster contains development plan summary and cost estimate for the initial phase of a large project.  Calculation of storable volumes was based upon the replacement method/  Probabilistic storable quantities were not reported.

site_name: Hewett Gas Fields Storage Site - 6 Hewett sst
publication: BP Exploration Operating Company Limited, 2021, Hewett Conclusive Report, NS051-SS-REP-000-00024
project_history: Cycle 4 update: This site sits within site CS008 of the UK NSTA license round for CO2 sites in 2023. ENI are the license holders. License awarded 01/07/2023. ENI have proposed a project to start at early as 2027 to help decarbonize the Bacton and Thames Estuary region. The Hewett field was initially assessed as a site for the Net Zero Teesside and Zero Carbon Humber Projects. Endurance was selected over Hewett due to larger capacity, less development cost and less risk of Joule-Thompson cooling effect.
development_plan: As outlined in the source document the following plan was proposed when Hewet was being considered against Endurance. It is not known if this plan still remains for the 2027 project ENI propose for the Bacton and Thames Estuary Region. Total Injection rate of 6Mpta of CO2 transported as liquid through a pipeline. The CO2 would be heated to avoid Joule Thompsons effect. Co2 would arrive at 81 bars to be transported to a reservoir of 4 bars. Four wells single completion type and one slot spare are considered.
containment_summary: The Hewett field is an elongate dome overlain by Triassic shales and evaporites which form the primary seal.  With many well penetrations from the exploration and development of this large gas field legacy well risk is considered a key containment risk.  This site has a Lower Bunter Hewett Sandstone reservoir target which sites below and separated from the Upper Bunter Sandstone
assessment_notes: The Hewett Conclusive Report, NS051-SS-REP-000-00024, 2021 provides an update to the status of the Hewett Field as a consideration for part of the Northern Endurance Partnership. An integrated reservoir study by ENI in Annex 0 NS051-RE-STU-434-00001 - Integrated reservoir study report with preliminary screening for CO2, combined with geochemical and geomechanically assessments find this site suitable for CO2 storage and a field capacity evaluated at 180 Mt for the Lower Bunter or Hewett Sandstones. The NZT/NEP estimate this more conservatively at 150 Mt for this interval.
author: KE
source_of_analogue: Integrated reservoir study and simulation

publication: Perenco, 2023, The Poseidon Project, https://perenco-ccs.com/the-poseidon-project/ (accessed 16/01/2024)
project_history: This site sits within site CS009 of the UK NSTA license round for CO2 sites in 2023. Perenco UK are the license holders with partner Carbon Catalyst. License awarded 01/07/2023.
development_plan: This site is part of the Poseidon Project. Perenco UK and the partner Carbon Catalyst Ltd will operate the site. The project is planned to decarbonise the East Anglia, Greater London and Southeast England. Projected to be online by 2029 with initial injection rates of around 1.5 Mtpa, rising to 10Mtpa by 2030, peaking at 40 Mtpa over a 40 year period. Information relating to the development plan is sourced from the Poseidon Project website
containment_summary: Containment has been considered in CO2Stored
assessment_notes: At cycle 4 there is limited data to update any assessment quantities. Development plans and injection rates are found on the Poseidon Project Website state that state  ultimate storage capacity including the Bunter closure 9 aquifer and other depleted fields is 935 Mt (https://www.energyvoice.com/renewables-energy-transition/ccs/552064/perenco-poseidon-orion-ccs/). Methodology to define this is not documented in literature. It is assumed that capacity studies have been performed by the license holder and therefore remain proprietary.  The Bunter Closure 9 resource  remains unchanged from cycle 1 due to lack of information in the literature on revised estimates for this field in the Poseidon project . There may be a risk of double counting here but as yet there is insufficient  information to verify this. A value of 1.5Mt *25 yrs (37.5) is given as justitfied for development at this site based on initial injection volume plans.. The remaining 897.5 Mt is classed as development unclarified due to lack of a development plan for this volume  until further reporting is available.
author: KE

Injecting 5Mt/yr in total with CO2 delivered by a new pipeline   Growth potential beyond this includes the Mey and Forties formations.

publication: Energy Technologies Institute ETI. 2015. “DECC Storage Appraisal: WP5E - Viking A Storage Development Plan 10113ETIS-Rep-21-03.”
project_history: Awarded Track 2 Cluster funding by the UK government in 2023. Licensed held By Harbour Energy and BP. Expected to be operational from as early as 2027, assuming government sequencing through its Track 2 process in 2023 and on a Final Investment Decision in 2024
development_plan: Harbour expects Viking CCS to start operating in 2027. The company aims to transport and store 10 MM metric tons per year of CO2 by 2030 and up to 15 MM metric tons by 2035.  Viking CCS will reuse existing pipelines and utilise decommissioned gas fields in the Southern North Sea . Detailed development plans are not in the public domain . Further details  on Viking website https://www.vikingccs.co.uk/about_x000D_
containment_summary:
There is a high level of confidence that over 130Mt of CO2 can be contained within the Leman Sandstone in the Viking A site._x000D_
_x000D_
• 1000 years after injection has ceased the CO2 plume is still contained within the Viking A structure and the defined storage complex._x000D_
_x000D_
• The primary top seal is provided by a 365m sequence of halites with interbedded anhydrites and carbonates of the Permian Zechstein_x000D_
_x000D_
Group._x000D_
_x000D_
• Underlying the Leman Sandstone is approximately 400 m (1200 ft) of Carboniferous sediments of Westphalian age. These are_x000D_
_x000D_
predominantly shales, clays and siltstone with low permeability. and provide an effective containment feature at the floor of the store._x000D_
_x000D_
• Viking has minimal risk of caprock or fault failure for the modelled stress conditions, reservoir and overburden properties and fault properties. No adverse geochemical reactions are anticipated with the reservoir or caprock that might reduce the formations strength and integrity.
assessment_notes: The primary source is a detailed storage development plan which included an assessment against a prototype SRMS system.  A 26 year injection duration was modelled.  Low estimate is based upon P90 probabilistic estimate from the source document. Mid estimate is the base case from the development plan and the high estimate comes from a calibrated probabilistic storage capacity estimate. Updated storage assessments are not available in the Public domain in Cycle 4.
author: KE
source_of_analogue: Storage efficiency was reported from a range of simulation sensitivity runs

publication: Energy Technologies Institute (ETI). 2015. “DECC Storage Appraisal: Prospect Summary Sheets.”
project_history: Awarded Track 2 Cluster funding by the UK government in 2023. Licensed held By Harbour Energy and BP. Expected to be operational from as early as 2027, assuming government sequencing through its Track 2 process in 2023 and on a Final Investment Decision in 2024
development_plan: Harbour expects Viking CCS to start operating in 2027. The company aims to transport and store 10 MM metric tons per year of CO2 by 2030 and up to 15 MM metric tons by 2035.  Viking CCS will reuse existing pipelines and utilise decommissioned gas fields in the Southern North Sea . Detailed development plans are not in the public domain . Further details  on Viking website https://www.vikingccs.co.uk/about
containment_summary: The Viking complex consists is a series of tilted fault blocks separated by large E-W trending normal faults.  The structured are overlain by thick Zechstein evaporites between 182 and 1372m thick which provide an excellent seal.  Key containment risk is associated with legacy wells.
assessment_notes: Source Poster contains development plan summary and cost estimate for the initial phase of a large project.  Calculation of storable volumes was based upon the replacement method.  Probabilistic storable quantities were not reported.  NOTE that this evaluation also includes Viking A. Updated and detailed storage assessments are not in the public domain for Cycle 4. However, ERCE has independently verified Harbour’s estimate of 300 million tonnes of contingent CO2 storage resources as detailed on the Viking Project website.
author: KE
source_of_analogue: Storable quantities estimated using replacement methodology

publication: Energy Technologies Institute (ETI). 2015. “DECC Storage Appraisal: Strategic UK CO2 Storage Appraisal - Project - Addendum.”

publication: Dressel, B. (2015). Recent Site Characterisation Studies Being Investigated by the Department of Energy (DOE)/National Energy Technology Laboratory (NETL) for Potential Geological Storage of CO2. Retrieved from: http://www.searchanddiscovery.com/documents/2015/80496dressel/ndx_dressel.pdf
project_history: Regionally-produced 5Mt CO2 emissions. SoCalCarb Research program evaluating Plio-Miocene sediments in Wilmington Graben (LA Basin offshore Long Beach Harbor area). Geomechanics Technologies study previously (?) estimated storage resource. New seismic data acquired plus 2 data wells drilled. No known current evaluation program.
development_plan: 4 scenarios simulated based on static geomodel. Injection likely to only be successful into Miocene sands at 2160m depth. Shallow (1500m) Pliocene sands do not retain injected CO2 (where modelled). Single injection well modelled. Updated resource estimate derived from Dressel, B. 2015: http://www.searchanddiscovery.com/documents/2015/80496dressel/ndx_dressel
assessment_notes: Discovered (2 wells drilled plus existing hydrocarbon province). Dynamic simulation. Storage resource updated 2019 using data for Miocene derived from Dressel 2015. CONTINGENT: DEVELOPMENT NOT VIABLE
author: SB

publication: Sarkus, T.A. (2015). Illinois Basin Decatur Project and ADM Industrial CCS Demonstration. Retrieved from: https://pubs.naruc.org/pub.cfm?id=4AE5E75F-2354-D714-51B7-59DE74C41F5E
project_history: Illinois Basin Decatur Project (IBDP) sourced CO2 from an ethanol fermentation plant with injection at the same site. CO2 injection started in Nov 2011 (1000 metric tonnes /day). Goal of 1 Mt injected CO2 met Nov 2014. Up to 10 years post-injection monitoring commenced. Goal was to prove storage potential of Mt Simon sst. Follow-on ICCS project at same location aims to inject up to 5Mt over 3 years starting 2017.
assessment_notes: Discovered. Capacity: Stored: 1Mt CO2 stored. Note: Mt Simon Sst storage potential estimated at 12-172 Gt.
author: SB
source_of_analogue: Simulation

storage_unit_type: Open, no identified structural/ stratigraphic confinement
publication: Gollakota, S. & McDonald, S. (2018). Successful demonstration of Illinois Industrial Carbon Capture and Storage in a saline reservoir. Proceedings 2018 AIChE Annual Meeting. Retrieved: https://www.aiche.org/conferences/aiche-annual-meeting/2018/proceeding/paper/329c-successful-demonstration-illinois-industrial-carbon-capture-and-storage-saline-reservoir
project_history: DOE Phase 1 & 2 Industrial CCS Program project. At same location as IBDP using CO2 from Archer Daniels ethanol plant and injecting into Mt Simon Sandstone. Currently (2019) the largest saline storage project in the USA. Key is aim is demonstrating cutting edge intelligent monitoring program.
development_plan: 1 injection well, 1 monitoring well (plus shallow geophones). Injection well permitted as a UIC Class VI well. 3D geocellular model (48 km x 48 km) used to develop numerical model. History matched using IBDP data. Model used to evaluate plume development and pressure perturbation using planned injection schedule: Year 1: 730,000t, years 2,3 & 4: 1000,000 t (running 52 year simulation period). Up to 5Mt injection over project life.  Plume interaction with IBDP expected.
containment_summary: Eau Claire Fm acts as primary seal with secondary seals identified. 50 years of natural gas storage in Mt Simon Sst provides confidence for safe storage. No wells (other than CCS wells) penetrate primary seal.
assessment_notes: COMMERCIAL: Stored: 640,000t (0.64 Mt; March 2018). On-Injection: 4,360,000 t (4.3 Mt). 2019 value taken from: https://netl.doe.gov/sites/default/files/netl-file/1100-Greenberg-2019-Pittsburgh-MGSC.pdf
author: SB
source_of_analogue: History-matched model based on 3D geocellular model

publication: Dressel, B. (2015). Recent Site Characterisation Studies Being Investigated by the Department of Energy (DOE)/National Energy Technology Laboratory (NETL) for Potential Geological Storage of CO2. Retrieved from: http://www.searchanddiscovery.com/documents/2015/80496dressel/ndx_dressel.pdf
project_history: Storage resource estimate from DOE Atlas V (2015). Pilot injection into Arbuckle Gp sandstones and dolomites sitting below Mississippian oil reservoirs. Test of combined geological storage in saline aquifer and CO2-EOR in oil field. 26sqkm 3D seismic, 488m core plus wireline data from 2 characterisation wells available. Injection into saline aquifer did not take place (well permit denied). 20,000 t injected into oil field for EOR.
development_plan: 1 injection well (Class VI) for injection into saline aquifer. I injection well (Class 2) for CO2-EOR in overlying oil reservoir. Project plan: 40,000 t CO2 injected into saline aquifer plus 30,000 t into overlying oil reservoir for EOR. Plume simulation model reported.
containment_summary: Saline aquifer section sits below Mississippian oil reservoirs with proven seals.
assessment_notes: DISCOVERED: Inaccessible (no well permit)
author: SB

site_name: Michigan Basin Niagaran Pinnacle Reef Trend Project
publication: Mawalkar, S., Burchwell, A., Gupta, N., Place, M., Kelley, M., Winecki, S., Mannes, R. and Pardini, R. 2018. “Achieving 1 million metric ton stored; measurement and accounting for net CO2 injection in a CO2-EOR complex.” 14th International Conference on Greenhouse Gas Control Technologies. Melbourne, Australia.
project_history: Storage resource estimate from DOE Atlas V (2015). Project examining injection of CO2 into northern (Michigan) Pinnacle Reef Trend oilfields. Series of closely-spaced, high compartmentalised reef structures. Produced oil and gas since 1960's with most fields near economic limit for primary production. Project leverages existing EOR operations to assess CO2 storage potential. Estimated storage potential of reefs: several hundred million tonnes.
development_plan: Project tested injection into 8 field at varying stages of field life cycle: 1 late stage (highly depleted, 6 active EOR, 1 recently put under primary production. Late stage reef (Dover 33) : 1 injection well plus 2 MVA wells. Injection of 271,000 took place between 2013-2016. Rate dependent on CO2 supply. EOR on-going.
containment_summary: Proven oil and gas fields.
assessment_notes: Commercial: Stored 0.27 Mt (271,000t); 2021 values from website: "stored 1,732,500 metric tonnes;" https://www.midwestccus.org/our-projects/ ; also cited in this paper: https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=3820174
author: SB

project_history: Originally a BSCSP DOE Phase III project (North-Central Montana) aimed at extracting naturally-occurring CO2 from Duperow FM at top of dome and re-injecting in brine-filled lower reservoir (1Mt/year). 3D seismic acquired and two data wells drilled but project focus changed after formation water discovered to have <10,000ppm TDS (also contains H2S). Updated (from 2014) dynamic simulation reduced max. mass of CO2 which can be injected over a 4 year period to be 1.2Mt (down from 5Mt).
assessment_notes: Discovered: 2 data wells drilled plus pre-existing wells down to injection zone depth. IRAP model using 1 injector built. Inaccessible due to low (<10000 ppm TDS) brine salinity.

publication: Dressel, B. (2015). Recent Site Characterisation Studies Being Investigated by the Department of Energy (DOE)/National Energy Technology Laboratory (NETL) for Potential Geological Storage of CO2. Retrieved from: http://www.searchanddiscovery.com/documents/2015/80496dressel/ndx_dressel.pdf
project_history: Storage resource estimate from DOE Atlas V (2015). Study of Mesozoic S. Georgia Rift Basin (extends from South Carolina into Georgia). 325 km 2D seismic & 1sq. mile 3D in SC. No known, active evaluation program.
development_plan: No details provided although DOE Atlas V mentions a numerical simulation model developed to investigate feasibility of injecting 30 Mt into Jurassic/Triassic sediments. Additional details provided by: http://www.searchanddiscovery.com/documents/2015/80496dressel/ndx_dressel
containment_summary: Preliminary study indicates multiple horizons with areal extent to store CO2, including mafic diabase units.
assessment_notes: PARTLY DISCOVERED. Contingent: Development Not Viable.

publication: DOE-NETL. (2015). Carbon Storage Atlas V. US Department of Energy.
project_history: DOE Phase III project undertaken by SWP group. Investigation of a current EOR project. Aim: permanently sequester 1Mt CO2 in an active EOR project. Data available: 110 km2 (42 sq mile) 3D, repeat 3D VSP surveys in injection wells. Note: Quarterly reports state that as of September 2018 the Phase III CO2 storage project did not meet its target of 1Mt but that this goal was met over the course of CO2 injection since 2010 with over 2Mt CO2 injected into the  field. No indication of recycled volume.
development_plan: 13 active CO2 injection wells. 3 additional site characterisation and monitoring wells. Primary objective: inject and monitor 1Mt CO2 over 5 years (190,000t/yr; equivalent: 10MMscf/day). Simulation model built. History-matched to primary and secondary production. project also developing fully coupled simulation with numerical-multifluid hydrologic-heat transport-reactive transport- geomechanical capabilities.
containment_summary: Actively producing oil field (under tertiary recovery). Overlying seal: Morrow Shale. Some faults interpreted from 3D seismic but these are not expected to compromise sealing performance.
assessment_notes: Discovered: Commercial. Stored: 1Mt. Preliminary assessment indicates >25 Mt storage capacity. Contingent: Development Not Viable: 24 Mt as no clear non-EOR related storage plan or dedicated permits for geological storage of CO2.
author: SB

Plains CO2 Reduction (PCOR) Partnership Phase III Value-Added Report. Prepared for NETL. Retrieved from: DOE-NETL. (2015). Carbon Storage Atlas V. US Department of Energy.
project_history: PCOR study (DOE-funded) reports on 3D geocellular model for several saline aquifers within PCOR area. Broom Creek is a Pennsylvanian-Permian, laterally-extensive sandstone sitting above the Minnelusa aquifer system in North and South Dakota. The aquifer was studied as part of the  DOE-funded Washburn Study. Storage resource estimate derived from table of values in Glaweski et al paper.
containment_summary: Overlain by Opeche Formation - a thick anhydritic shale.
assessment_notes: UNDISCOVERED. Prospective: Sequence Play
author: SB
source_of_analogue: Gorecki et al. (IEAGHG) volumetric method as reported in DOE Atlas III & IV. Cut-offs: 'no 'unconfined' areas of saline system, CO2 in dense phase (>800m depth), salinity <10,000 mg/L TDS. Storage efficiency coefficients from DOE atlas applied(for clastic sediments). Low: 0.51%, Mid: 2.0%. High: 5.5%.

storage_unit_type: Open, no identified structural/ stratigraphic confinement
publication: Liu, G., Peck, W.D., Braunberger, J.R., Klenner, R.C., Gorecki, C.D., Steadman, E.N. & Harju, J.A. (2014). “Evaluation of large-scale carbon dioxide storage potential in the basal saline system in the Alberta and Williston Basins in North America.” Energy Procedia 63 2911-2920.
project_history: Liu et al reports on results of COSS system-wide 3D geocellular model of Alberta and Williston basins. Total static resource estimate for USA/Canada (P50): 373 Gt. Estimated fraction of resource in USA: 24.78% (Peck et al, 2013). The Cambro-Ord Basal Sand is present in Montana, North & South Dakota and NE Wyoming. Additional (2015) PCOR report gives P50 resource estimate of 420 GT but uses extremely high storage efficiency factors (P50: 14%) but provides no supporting information. In this Assessment the lower 9.1% value for E applied by Liu et al. (2014) is preferred.
development_plan: None reported for USA sector of COSS model.
containment_summary: Note: Basal sand crops out in SD and Mt
assessment_notes: UNDISCOVERED: Prospective: Sequence Play
author: SB
source_of_analogue: Gorecki et al. (IEAGHG) volumetric method as reported in DOE Atlas III & IV. Cut-offs: 'no 'unconfined' areas of saline system, CO2 in dense phase (>800m depth), salinity <10,000 mg/L, >10 porosity. E factors applied: P10: 4.7%, P50: 9.1%, P90: 15.6%

publication: Glazewski, K.A., Grove, M.M, Peck, W.D., Gorecki, C.D., Steadman, E.N. & Harju, J.A. (2015). Characterisation of the PCOR partnership Region. formation: Weber Sst, Tensleep Sst, Madison Lst
storage_unit_type: Open, no identified structural/ stratigraphic confinement
publication: Surdam, R.C. (2013).The WY-CUSP Program: Working to deliver a certified commercial CO2 storage site to Wyoming. Carbon Management Institute. Retrieved from: https://www.netl.doe.gov/sites/default/files/event-proceedings/2013/carbon%20storage/4-20-WYCUSP_08-2013_Surdam.pdf
project_history: Storage resource estimate from DOE Atlas V (2015). Evaluation of Pennsylvanian Weber and Tensleep Ssts and Mississippian Madison Lst at the Rock Springs Uplift (Greater Green River Basin in SW WY). Stratigraphic test and data well drilled plus 3D seismic acquired. No known, current evaluation program.
development_plan: 3D static model developed of reservoir and seal units. Plume migration simulations undertaken. In-situ (small-scale) water injectivity measurements made.
containment_summary: 5 identified seals below potable water aquifer
assessment_notes: DISCOVERED. CONTINGENT DEVELOPMENT NOT VIABLE.

publication: DET NORSKE VERITAS. (2013). A Preliminary CO2Storage Atlas of Saline Aquifers in the Mozambique Basin. DET NORSKE VERITAS, OLJE-OGENERGIDEPARTEMENTET. DET NORSKE VERITAS.
project_history: Storage resource potential based on DNV CO2 Storage Atlas of Mozambique Basin (2013). Using geological data (including cross-sections and log data) four saline reservoir -seal pairs identified: the Sena Formation, the Domo Sands, and the Upper and Lower Grudja Formation.19 well bores and 5 cross-sections used to delineate regional 'zones' suitable for CO2 storage based on aquifer presence and extent.
containment_summary: All saline aquifers identified have a shale seal pair. Both stratigraphic and structural trapping styles identified in the Mozambique basin.
assessment_notes: Undiscovered: Inaccessible due to current lack of regulatory system. Basin-scale resource estimate comprises sum of estimates for four saline aquifers (Sena Fm, Domo sands, Lower and upper Grudja Formations). No value attached to this entry to avoid double accounting.
author: SB
source_of_analogue: DOE 2008

publication: DET NORSKE VERITAS. (2013). A Preliminary CO2Storage Atlas of Saline Aquifers in the Mozambique Basin. DET NORSKE VERITAS, OLJE-OGENERGIDEPARTEMENTET. DET NORSKE VERITAS.
project_history: Storage resource potential based on DNV CO2 Storage Atlas of Mozambique Basin (2013). Using geological data (including cross-sections and log data) four saline reservoir -seal pairs identified: the Sena Formation, the Domo Sands, and the Upper and Lower Grudja Formation.19 well bores and 5 cross-sections used to delineate regional 'zones' suitable for CO2 storage based on aquifer presence and extent.
containment_summary: Sena Formation alluvial clastics (2000-2500m thick) are discordantly overlain by Lower domo Shale formation sediments (marine argillites with sand-prone lenses). Formation thickness at Pande gas field is 120m. Depth range for assessment (reservoir): 1894-3218m
assessment_notes: Partly Discovered - Awaiting detailed assessment (no simulation of site available): 4% of the site is 'Discovered' by the existing wells in the delineated zone. Discovered: 3.7 Mt, Undiscovered: Sequence Play: 89 Mt. Lack of published regulations mean the site is Inaccessible at present.  Resource calculation assumptions (volumetric approach): hydrostatic pressure assumed, geothermal gradient of 30 degC/km, CO2 density calculated using TREND software, depth, thickness and NTG from well records (represents average value), porosity from data or porosity-depth correlation derived from basin-wide data. Each storage resource 'zone' identified assumes homogenous properties of NTG and porosity. Storage efficiency calculated using 1% (low-end) and 2% (high end). No information provided on how mid range value calculated.
author: SB
source_of_analogue: DOE 2008

publication: DET NORSKE VERITAS. (2013). A Preliminary CO2Storage Atlas of Saline Aquifers in the Mozambique Basin. DET NORSKE VERITAS, OLJE-OGENERGIDEPARTEMENTET. DET NORSKE VERITAS.
project_history: Storage resource potential based on DNV CO2 Storage Atlas of Mozambique Basin (2013). Using geological data (including cross-sections and log data) four saline reservoir -seal pairs identified: the Sena Formation, the Domo Sands, and the Upper and Lower Grudja Formation.19 well bores and 5 cross-sections used to delineate regional 'zones' suitable for CO2 storage based on aquifer presence and extent.
containment_summary: Interbedded sands with shale interbeds (95m thick at Pande gas field) are overlain by Upper Domo shale formation  (675m thick at Pande gas field). Depth range for assessment (reservoir): 2005-2782m
assessment_notes: Partly Discovered - Awaiting detailed assessment (no simulation of site available): 4.7% of the site is 'Discovered' by the existing wells in the delineated zone. Discovered: 9.4 Mt, Undiscovered: Sequence Play: 190.6 Mt. Lack of published regulations mean the site is Inaccessible at present. Resource calculation assumptions (volumetric approach): hydrostatic pressure assumed, geothermal gradient of 30 degC/km, CO2 density calculated using TREND software, depth, thickness and NTG from well records (represents average value), porosity from data or porosity-depth correlation derived from basin-wide data. Each storage resource 'zone' identified assumes homogenous properties of NTG and porosity. Storage efficiency calculated using 1% (low-end) and 2% (high end). No information provided on how mid range value calculated.
author: SB
source_of_analogue: DOE 2008

site_name: Lower Grudja Formation aquifer: Atlas Zone 1
publication: DET NORSKE VERITAS. (2013). A Preliminary CO2Storage Atlas of Saline Aquifers in the Mozambique Basin. DET NORSKE VERITAS, OLJE-OGENERGIDEPARTEMENTET. DET NORSKE VERITAS.
project_history: Storage resource potential based on DNV CO2 Storage Atlas of Mozambique Basin (2013). Using geological data (including cross-sections and log data) four saline reservoir -seal pairs identified: the Sena Formation, the Domo Sands, and the Upper and Lower Grudja Formation.19 well bores and 5 cross-sections used to delineate regional 'zones' suitable for CO2 storage based on aquifer presence and extent.
containment_summary: Lower Grudja is the primary gas-bearing formation in Mozambique (8 reservoir sand section 830m thick at Pande gas field). Shaley marls and thin limestones sequences (3-6m thick at the top of the formation). Depth range for assessment (reservoir: 1114-1263m)
assessment_notes: Partly Discovered - Awaiting detailed assessment (no simulation of site available): 1.7% of the site is 'Discovered' by the existing wells in the delineated zone. Discovered: 11.8 Mt, Undiscovered: Sequence Play: 688 Mt. Lack of published regulations mean the site is Inaccessible at present. Resource calculation assumptions (volumetric approach): hydrostatic pressure assumed, geothermal gradient of 30 degC/km, CO2 density calculated using TREND software, depth, thickness and NTG from well records (represents average value), porosity from data or porosity-depth correlation derived from basin-wide data. Each storage resource 'zone' identified assumes homogenous properties of NTG and porosity. Storage efficiency calculated using 1% (low-end) and 2% (high end). No information provided on how mid range value calculated.

site_name: Upper Grudja Formation aquifer: Atlas Zone 1
publication: DET NORSKE VERITAS. (2013). A Preliminary CO2Storage Atlas of Saline Aquifers in the Mozambique Basin. DET NORSKE VERITAS, OLJE-OGENERGIDEPARTEMENTET. DET NORSKE VERITAS.
project_history: Storage resource potential based on DNV CO2 Storage Atlas of Mozambique Basin (2013). Using geological data (including cross-sections and log data) four saline reservoir -seal pairs identified: the Sena Formation, the Domo Sands, and the Upper and Lower Grudja Formation.19 well bores and 5 cross-sections used to delineate regional 'zones' suitable for CO2 storage based on aquifer presence and extent.
containment_summary: Interbedded Upper Grudja clastics (sands and shales) and limestones (490 m thick) are overlain by Middle-Upper Eocene Cheringoma formation carbonates. Depth range for assessment (reservoir): 1103-1179m).
assessment_notes: Partly Discovered - Awaiting detailed assessment (no simulation of site available): 7% of the site is 'Discovered' by the existing wells in the delineated zone. Discovered:  Mt, Undiscovered: Sequence Play:  Mt. Lack of published regulations mean the site is Inaccessible at present. Resource calculation assumptions (volumetric approach): hydrostatic pressure assumed, geothermal gradient of 30 degC/km, CO2 density calculated using TREND software, depth, thickness and NTG from well records (represents average value), porosity from data or porosity-depth correlation derived from basin-wide data. Each storage resource 'zone' identified assumes homogenous properties of NTG and porosity. Storage efficiency calculated using 1% (low-end) and 2% (high end). No information provided on how mid range value calculated.
author: SB
source_of_analogue: DOE 2008

publication: Júlio F. Carneiro, M. A. (2014). Preliminary assessment of CO2 storage potential in the Rovuma sedimentary basin, Mozambique. Energy Procedia , 63.
project_history: Study by Carneiro and alberto (2014) evaluated storage potentail of the late Mesozoic-Cenozoic sedimentary basin-fill. Two sectors considered to have storage potential.
containment_summary: Intraformational shales within the Mikindani. No details of seals to Alto Jingone/Quissanga formations, although offshore equivalents host M'nazi Bay gas field.
assessment_notes: Undiscovered: Sequence play. Assessed as Inaccessible due to lack of CCS specific regulatory framework. Inputs for volumetric resource estimate derived from offshore gas field (M'nazi Bay field). Porosity: 11-25%, NTG: 3-31%. Published values are given as low and high. In this assessment the low value is considered the mid-range value. Storage efficiency values 2-4% utilised.
author: SB
source_of_analogue: EU Geocapacity Vangkilde-Pederson et al 2009

publication: Asian Development Bank. (2013). Prospects for Carbon Capture and Storage in Southeast Asia. Mandaluyong City, Philippines.
project_history: The basis of this report was to assess south east asia for CO2 storage by source and sink matching, for Thailand, the best resources close to large emitters are in the gulf of Thailand. Note: due to a lack of geographic location data, the lat/long provided for this site is inaccurate. The majority of potential sites sit offshore within teh Gulf of Thailand however there are up to 5 onshore unidentified sites.
containment_summary: Not specified
assessment_notes: Discovered: Inaccessible. Discovered because petroleum has been produced from each field therefore there must be one if not a cluster of wells. Inaccessible because Thailand does not have any specific CCS policies or regulations. Each field is accompanied by a suitability score which takes into account the following criteria: Capacity, injection rate (per well), seal thickness, number of abandoned wells and contamination of other reservoirs. it also accounts for some economic criteria: existing infrastructure, monitoring opportunities, availability and willingness of operator. the best storage candidates close to large emitters are located in the Gulf of Thailand. Cumulative production data for oil, gas and water (including injection) was used to calculate replacement volumes for these gas fields. Annual production and proven reserve was used to estimate when oil and gas fields would become available for CO2 storage, 90% of the resource here will be available for storage by 2020. Besides storage resources and suitability score however, data is quite poor for these fields, I.e there is no formation data and it is not possible to locate specific fields on the map figure. The 'Inaccessible' classification also applies to this lack of geographic locater. If updated information becomes available to refine the geographic identification Figure A3.5 in the ADB (2013) report should be evaluated to avoid new sites resulting in double accounting of resources.

source_of_analogue: O&G Replacement volume

publication: Apichat Choomkong, S. S. (2020, February ). 3D Modeling of CO2 Geological Storage of Songkhla Sub- Basins in the Lower Gulf of Thailand. INTERNATIONAL JOURNAL OF INTEGRATED ENGINEERING , 12.
project_history: This paper recognises that Thailand needs to reduce it's emissions by 125Mt in the next 13 years in order stay inline with their UNFCC agreement. This study focusses in on the Power Development Plan (PDP) 2015, this plan was created by the Thai government in order to reduce CO2 emissions from the county's power sector. The paper is split into two parts. Part one: locate CO2 sources and determine their rates of emissions,  part two link these sources up to viable storage options in sedimentary basins that have petroleum activity and data.
containment_summary: Not specified, but as all of these resources are based on produced and proven reserves of petroleum, we can deduce that there will be a trap for free phase CO2 and that the seal is proven to hold oil and gas in place.
assessment_notes: Discovered: Inaccessible. Discovered because these resource estimates were made using cumulative replacement volumes for both produced and proven reserves in the basin. Inaccessible because Thailand does not have any specific CCS policies or regulations. This site entry represents cumulative replacement volumes of produced and proven reserves from oil and gas fields in this basin - it does not account for any aquifer pore volumes. Specifically, these replacement volumes were calculated by converting Gas STP volumes to equivalent CO2 Tonnage stored (1Tcf = ~80Mt CO2), this result is then multiplied by density of CO2. To convert OIL STP volumes to equivalent CO2 tonnage stored, a pressure of 10.5 MPa/km and geothermal gradients of 30-35๐ C/km were used. The density of CO2 between 1,500-4,000 meters deep in the subsurface is about 700 kg/m3, and the FVF was assumed to be 1.2.
author: AW
source_of_analogue: O&G Replacement volume

publication: Kreangkrai Maneeintra, N. R. (2017). AssessmentofCO2Geological Storage Potential in a Depleted Oil. 4th International Conference on Power and Energy Systems Engineering. Berlin : Energy Procedia.
project_history: This paper aimed to help kickstart CCS research in Thailand in order to reduce CO2 emissions to atmosphere. The CO2 to be stored in at this site would be captured from the Mae Moh coal fired powerplant , which emits 13Mt CO2 a year (as of 2013). The model created here is to be used as a fundamental example of CO2 storage in depleted petroleum fields in onshore Thailand.
development_plan: None available, dynamic simulation run using CMG (GEM) software, reservoir info for fang oilfield from Defense Energy Department.
containment_summary: Not Specified, it is assumed to be an open formation, therefore after injection CO2 is shown to migrate laterally along the sand layer.
assessment_notes: Discovered: Inaccessible. Discovered because the storage simulation is within a depleted oil field, and Inaccessible because Thailand does not have any specific CCS policies or regulations. Three simple simulations (GEM) at rates of: 1000, 2000, & 3000 Tons/day, without exceeding maximum working pressure of 32.29MPa, and 50 years of shut in for all.
author: AW
source_of_analogue: Dynamic simulation

publication: Apichat Choomkong, S. S. (2020, February ). 3D Modeling of CO2 Geological Storage of Songkhla Sub- Basins in the Lower Gulf of Thailand. INTERNATIONAL JOURNAL OF INTEGRATED ENGINEERING , 12.
project_history: This paper realises the problems of global warming and Thailand's commitment to reduce emissions by 140Mt by 2030. The country has increasing electricity demand to drive the growing economy (in 2014 70% electricity from fossil fuels ). The Power Development Plan (2015) mentions that the Songkhla province southern Thailand is forecast to experience a considerable increase in electricity demand. The Department of Mineral Fuels, under the Ministry of energy is the responsible government agency for CCS in Thailand. In this study, daily injection rates and volumes are based on that of the nearby Chana Powerplant (1500MW/Year Capacity) from 01 September 2014 - 01 August 2017. it is also noted that the reservoirs within this AOI can support a clean coal project with 200MW/year capacity in the near future.
development_plan: Daily injectivity dynamic simulations is based off that of the Chana power plant from 2014 - 2017. The formation pressure in the simulation has been set to not exceed the initial pressure of 224 Bar. Well A (an existing well) has been chosen for injection as it penetrates the area of highest porosity in the static model. Injection is simulated for  3 years.  the Bua-Ban field is 50km north of CO2 emissions from the Chana power plant.
containment_summary: the static geo model accounts for primary porosity (deposition and lithification) and secondary porosity (fracturing & jointing) based on geological setting and geophysical data. The simulation shows the  CO2 plume will migrate updip to the west after injection, the plume appears to cross a permeable  fault zone. No mention is given about the seal rock.
assessment_notes: Discovered: Inaccessible. Discovered as there are more wells than needed within the AOI in order for it to be 100% discovered, the Bua-Ban field which contains modelled blocks SLO and SLM, the AOI covers an area of  ~280km^2. The resource is inaccessible because Thailand does not have any specific CCS policies or regulations. A static model was created on Petrel using data from 164 well logs in the area and local geophysical data. The dynamic simulation was run in Eclipse Ver. 2017, injection rate matched the volumes emitted by the Chana powerplant (2014-2017) and the pressure limit was set at 224 Bar.
author: AW
source_of_analogue: Dynamic simulation

publication: Asian Development Bank. (2013). Prospects for Carbon Capture and Storage in Southeast Asia. Mandaluyong City, Philippines.
project_history: The basis of this report was to assess south east asia for CO2 storage by source and sink matching, for Thailand, the best resources close to large emitters are in the gulf of Thailand. Note: due to a lack of geographic location data, the lat/long provided for this site is inaccurate. The majority of potential sites sit offshore within teh Gulf of Thailand however there are up to 5 onshore unidentified sites.
containment_summary: Not specified
assessment_notes: Discovered: Inaccessible. Discovered because petroleum has been produced from each field therefore there must be one if not a cluster of wells. Inaccessible because Thailand does not have any specific CCS policies or regulations. Each field is accompanied by a suitability score which takes into account the following criteria: Capacity, injection rate (per well), seal thickness, number of abandoned wells and contamination of other reservoirs. it also accounts for some economic criteria: existing infrastructure, monitoring opportunities, availability and willingness of operator. the best storage candidates close to large emitters are located in the Gulf of Thailand. Cumulative production data for oil, gas and water (including injection) was used to calculate replacement volumes for these gas fields. Annual production and proven reserve was used to estimate when oil and gas fields would become available for CO2 storage, 90% of the resource here will be available for storage by 2020. Besides storage resources and suitability score however, data is quite poor for these fields, I.e there is no formation data and it is not possible to locate specific fields on the map figure. The 'Inaccessible' classification also applies to this lack of geographic locater. If updated information becomes available to refine the geographic identification Figure A3.5 in the ADB (2013) report should be evaluated to avoid new sites resulting in double accounting of resources.

source_of_analogue: O&G Replacement volume
