Each field is accompanied by a suitability score which takes into account the following criteria: Capacity, injection rate (per well), seal thickness, number of abandoned wells and contamination of other reservoirs. it also accounts for some economic criteria: existing infrastructure, monitoring opportunities, availability and willingness of operator. the best storage candidates close to large emitters are located in the Gulf of Thailand. Cumulative production data for oil, gas and water (including injection) was used to calculate replacement volumes for these gas fields. Annual production and proven reserve was used to estimate when oil and gas fields would become available for CO2 storage, 90% of the resource here will be available for storage by 2020. Besides storage resources and suitability score however, data is quite poor for these fields, I.e there is no formation data and it is not possible to locate specific fields on the map figure. The 'Inaccessible' classification also applies to this lack of geographic locater. If updated information becomes available to refine the geographic identification Figure A3.5 in the ADB (2013) report should be evaluated to avoid new sites resulting in double accounting of resources.

site_name: Saline Aquifer Gulf of Thailand  - under CO2-rich gas field (J Group)
publication: CO2CRC Technologies Pty Ltd. (2010). Assessment of the capture and storage potential of CO2 co-produced with natural gas in South-East Asia. The University of New South Wales, School of Petroleum Engineering. Sydney, Australia: Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation.
project_history: One of the aims od this paper is to help facilitate production of south east Asia's high CO2 fields, some of these fields have a CO2 content of 70% and above, in order to legally produce these, the operator must store their CO2 in a subsea formation closely located to the production well. Therefore this paper presents storage options and development plans for the CO2 from these high CO2 fields.
development_plan: A simple simulation was conducted to determine the maximum rate of CO2 that can be injected over the injection period (20 years) without the pressure in the reservoir exceeding its fracture pressure. Sensitivities were carried out on the number of wells required. The volume of CO2 modelled was based on production modelling. The analyses implicitly assume injection sites with the reservoir properties assumed for the sedimentary basin where they are located.CO2 injected into saline formation underneath the CO2-rich gas field. Steel Jacket platform, 3 deviated wells injecting a total of 3.5Mt/y, 10km 850mm pipeline with 3MW of compression.
containment_summary: The development plan proposes injection into the same unit (L Group) as the high-CO2 gas field. Although a simple simulation has been conducted, no simulation modelling has been carried out to understand possible migration of injected CO2 into the structure as the gas field is produced. The permeability of 500mD, however, may provide a containment challenge, where injected CO2 migrates into the depleting field.
assessment_notes: Undiscovered, Inaccessible. Inaccessible due to the lack of CCS regulatory framework in Vietnam. A simple simulation was conducted to determine the maximum rate of CO2 that can be injected over the injection period (20 years) without the pressure in the reservoir exceeding its fracture pressure. However, the reservoir properties are subject to large uncertainties and variations due to the lithology type, more work is needed to properly model CO2 storage in this saline aquifer. Low confidence for coordinates given here.
author: AW
source_of_analogue: Dynamic simulation

publication: Asian Development Bank. (2013). Prospects for Carbon Capture and Storage in Southeast Asia. Mandaluyong City, Philippines.
project_history: The basis of this report was to assess south east asia for CO2 storage by source and sink matching, for Thailand, the best resources close to large emitters are in the gulf of Thailand. Note: due to a lack of geographic location data, the lat/long provided for this site is inaccurate. The majority of potential sites sit offshore within teh Gulf of Thailand however there are up to 5 onshore unidentified sites.
containment_summary: Not specified
assessment_notes: Undiscovered: Inaccessible. Only aquifers below 1000m included in this resource calculation. And only 10 out of Thailand's 94 basins/ sub-basins had sufficient data available to calculate storage resource. Additional Saline aquifer screening work done in this report include the following attributes: coordinated of the basin, basin depth, percentage of permeable sediments, average pressure and temperature of each basin. One basin alone accounts for 65% of this storage resource - the report gives no mention of which basin.

Cumulative production data for oil, gas and water (including injection) was used to calculate replacement volumes for these gas fields. Annual production and proven reserve was used to estimate when oil and gas fields would become available for CO2 storage, 90% of the resource here will be available for storage by 2020. Besides storage resources and suitability score however, data is quite poor for these fields, I.e there is no formation data and it is not possible to locate specific fields on the map figure. The 'Inaccessible' classification also applies to this lack of geographic locater. If updated information becomes available to refine the geographic identification Figure A3.5 in the ADB (2013) report should be evaluated to avoid new sites resulting in double accounting of resources.
author: AW
source_of_analogue: O&G Replacement volume

publication: Asian Development Bank. (2013). Prospects for Carbon Capture and Storage in Southeast Asia. Mandaluyong City, Philippines.

The majority of potential sites sit offshore within teh Gulf of Thailand however there are up to 5 onshore unidentified sites.

publication: Ajayi Temitope, J. S., & Jialiang Hu, A. (2016, November ). Characterization and Quantification of the CO2 Sequestration Potential of aCarbonate Aquifer in Falaha Syncline, Onshore Abu Dhabi. SPE-183442-MS.
project_history: This study builds on some of Ajayi's work from 2016 where a site selection was done, and some simulation work was done for the Shuiaba aquifer - but none of the other more shallow aquifers that are also located in this AOI
development_plan: Simulations were run using GEM to account for structural (free phase trapping), solubility trapping and residual/ capillary trapping. Mineralisation was also taken into account. Simulations at a range of salinities, 50,000 to 300,000ppm. The simulation at 50,000ppm had the highest resource estimate. The fractured pressure of the rock was estimated using a fracture gradient of 0.8psi/ft. Simulations Did not allow the aquifer to exceed it's fracture pressure. 5 vertical wells were selected for injection in the models. In both cases the injection duration was 100 years.
containment_summary: None specified, but the author did carry out similar containment studies as mentioned for the Simsima aquifer below, these were not presented in the results section.
author: AW
source_of_analogue: Dynamic simulation

publication: Ajayi Temitope, J. S., & Jialiang Hu, A. (2016, November ). Characterization and Quantification of the CO2 Sequestration Potential of aCarbonate Aquifer in Falaha Syncline, Onshore Abu Dhabi. SPE-183442-MS.
project_history: This study builds on some of Ajayi's work from 2016 where a site selection was done, and some simulation work was done for the Shuiaba aquifer - but none of the other more shallow aquifers that are also located in this AOI
development_plan: Simulations were run using GEM to account for structural (free phase trapping), solubility trapping and residual/ capillary trapping. Mineralisation was also taken into account. Simulations at a range of salinities, 50,000 to 300,000ppm. The simulation at 50,000ppm had the highest resource estimate. The fractured pressure of the rock was estimated using a fracture gradient of 0.8psi/ft. Simulations Did not allow the aquifer to exceed it's fracture pressure. 5 vertical wells were selected for injection in the models. In both cases the injection duration was 100 years.
containment_summary: At end of injection 20% of gas is trapped by dissolution, 3% by residual and 77% remained in free phase. After 500 years, 28% pf gas is trapped in pores by residual trapping and 20% of the gas remains dissolved. It is noted the amount of residual trapped gas will further increase due to convection within the aquifer.
assessment_notes: Undiscovered in accessible. Undiscovered because even though there are wells that penetrate this aquifer, they have not technically discovered it as they were only running GR data acquisition and which can't give porosity values and no core or chipping analyses was done at these intervals.  The resource is inaccessible because Abu Dhabi does not possess the necessary legal and regulatory framework for ccs activities. If a regulatory framework was put in place for the UAE then this site would be promoted to undiscovered, Sequence as formation details are given. It is mentioned that the static models were created using data from 4768 wells from 10 most important fields of onshore Abu Dhabi, as well as regional seismic surfaces. Additional control wells were used from fields outside the area of interest. however as these wells can't be located on a map - we can't tell what proportion of this site is discovered. It is noted that for all but the Shuaiba aquifer, the penetrating wells don't posses desirable data as these upper intervals are not hydrocarbon targets therefore only gamma data was acquired at these depths. Given project status as it is clear that due diligence was done to find most effective locations for the 5 injection wells (Optimization algorithm).
author: AW
source_of_analogue: Dynamic simulation

publication: Ajayi Temitope, J. S., & Jialiang Hu, A. (2016, November ). Characterization and Quantification of the CO2 Sequestration Potential of aCarbonate Aquifer in Falaha Syncline, Onshore Abu Dhabi. SPE-183442-MS.
project_history: This study builds on some of Ajayi's work from 2016 where a site selection was done, and some simulation work was done for the Shuiaba aquifer - but none of the other more shallow aquifers that are also located in this AOI
containment_summary: Not specified.
assessment_notes: Undiscovered in accessible. Undiscovered because even though there are wells that penetrate this aquifer, they have not technically discovered it as they were only running GR data acquisition and which can't give porosity values and no core or chipping analyses was done at these intervals.  The resource is  inaccessible because Abu Dhabi does not possess the necessary legal and regulatory framework for ccs activities. If a regulatory framework was put in place for the UAE then this site would be promoted to undiscovered, Sequence as formation details are given. It is mentioned that the static models were created using data from 4768 wells from 10 most important fields of onshore Abu Dhabi, as well as regional seismic surfaces. Additional control wells were used from fields outside the area of interest. however as these wells can't be located on a map - we can't tell what proportion of this site is discovered. Only the value using the DOE coefficient has been presented here. The other values calculated were both lower than the DOE method and were calculated using CSLF and Zhou (confined aquifer) coefficients with values of: 8455.16Mt and 1050Mt.
author: AW
source_of_analogue: Volumetric - from static model

publication: Asian Development Bank, “Prospects for Carbon Capture and Storage in Southeast Asia,” Mandaluyong City, Philippines, 2013.
project_history: The only previous work in this area is published in CO2 CRC, 2010   "Assessment of the capture and storage potential of CO2 co-produced with natural gas in South-East Asia"
containment_summary: Only storage in structural/ stratigraphic traps was considered for these saline aquifer formations, if all containment options were considered then Vietnams cumulative storage resource estimate for saline aquifers would increase from 10Gt to 300Gt.
assessment_notes: Undiscovered: Inaccessible. Only saline aquifers with petroleum plays were considered, and not barren aquifers that have never held or transported petroleum. If these were considered it would also add the  resource estimate.
author: AW
source_of_analogue: Volumetric analysis, no Storage efficiency given

publication: H.Thanh, Y. Sugai, R.Nguele, K.Sasaki,  "Integrated workflow in 3D geological model construction for evaluation of CO2 storage capacity of a fractured basement reservoir in Cuu Long Basin, Vietnam. 2019.
project_history: Previous studies of the region that present resources include: CO2CRC, 2010 and Asian Development Bank 2013.
development_plan: This resource is based on combined CO2 storage and EOR plan where CO2 can be permanently stored in the lower fractured basement section of the reservoir
containment_summary: CO2 will ultimately be contained by the Lacustrine Shale of sequences D & E which act as the source rock for hydrocarbons and the seal.
assessment_notes: Discovered: inaccessible. This is because Vietnam has not developed any legal or regulatory frameworks to support CCS activity in the region. If such a framework was created then this sight could be promoted to Dev. Not Viable.      The majority of this study focuses on techniques used to create the static geological model of fractured basement reservoir from Seismic, drill log por and perm and flow test data.
author: AW
source_of_storage_efficiency_factor: Bradshaw et al. CO2 storage capacity estimation: Issues and development of standards. 2005, 2007.
source_of_analogue: Volumetric - from static model

site_name: Saline Aquifer offshore Vietnam - under CO2-rich gas field (J Group)
publication: CO2CRC Technologies Pty Ltd, “Assessment of the capture and storage potential of CO2 co-produced with natural gas in South-East Asia,” Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation, Sydney, Australia, 2010.
project_history: Not Specified
development_plan: A simple simulation was conducted to determine the maximum rate of CO2 that can be injected over the injection period (20 years) without the pressure in the reservoir exceeding its fracture pressure. Sensitivities were carried out on the number of wells required. The volume of CO2 modelled was based on production modelling. The analyses implicitly assume injection sites with the reservoir properties assumed for the sedimentary basin where they are located.CO2 injected into saline formation underneath the CO2-rich gas field. Steel Jacket platform, 4 deviated wells injecting a total of 1.3Mt/y, 10km 150mm pipeline with 3MW of compression
containment_summary: The development plan proposes injection into the same unit (J Group) as the high-CO2 gas field. Although a simple simulation has been conducted, no simulation modelling has been carried out to understand possible migration of injected CO2 into the structure as the gas field is produced. The permeability of 100mD, however, may provide a containment challenge, where injected CO2 migrates into the depleting field.
assessment_notes: Undiscovered, inaccessible. Inaccessible due to the lack of CCS regulatory framework in Vietnam. A simple simulation was conducted to determine the maximum rate of CO2 that can be injected over the injection period (20 years) without the pressure in the reservoir exceeding its fracture pressure. However, the reservoir properties are subject to large uncertainties and variations due to the lithology type, more work is needed to properly model CO2 storage in this saline aquifer.
author: AW

publication: Asian Development Bank. (2013). Prospects for Carbon Capture and Storage in Southeast Asia. Mandaluyong City, Philippines.
project_history: The basis of this report was to assess south east asia for CO2 storage by source and sink matching, for Vietnam the  best storage resources for emitters lie in the Cuu Long basin.
containment_summary: Not specified
assessment_notes: Discovered: Inaccessible. Discovered because petroleum has been produced from each field therefore there must be one if not a cluster of wells. Inaccessible because Vietnam does not have any specific CCS policies or regulations. The best storage targets are in the Cuu Long basin – this has been verified by a suitability score, calculated for each field. Besides storage resources and suitability score however, data is quite poor for these fields, I.e there is no formation data and it is not possible to locate specific fields on the map figure. Storage estimates were calculated by replacement volume.
author: AW
source_of_analogue: O&G Replacement volume

The best storage targets are in the Cuu Long basin – this has been verified by a suitability score, calculated for each field. Besides storage resources and suitability score however, data is quite poor for these fields, I.e there is no formation data and it is not possible to locate specific fields on the map figure. Storage estimates were calculated by replacement volume.
author: AW
source_of_analogue: O&G Replacement volume

publication: BP Exploration Operating Company Limited, 2022, Multi-Store Development Philosophy Key Knowledge Document, NS051-SS-PHI-000-00010
project_history: This site is part of the Northern Endurance plan
development_plan: The alternative expansion strategy for Endurance in order to achieve Phase 2 injection rates (10 MTPA average), is to inject into other nearby Bunter stores – the Bunter Closures  36, 37, 39 and 40. This is to remove the brine from Endurance and retain safe reservoir pressure.
containment_summary: An overburden evaluation is reported.  The site is a simple 4 way dip closure. Primary seal is over 700m of Triassic mudstones and evaporites.  Key containment risk is associated with legacy wells.
assessment_notes: Revised volumes have been assessed in in  Key Knowledge Document (NS051-SS-PHI-000-00010). Bunter closure 39 lacks data to demonstrate injectivity and have slightly differnet reservoir properties from Endurance. P50 Volumetrics indicate volume with brine pressure management of 376 MT and without brine pressure management of 83 MT. The revised volume of 83 MT is taken as P50 estimate to provide the more realistic volume based on the Endurance development plan.

development_plan: No project planned however any development plan could be challenged by the planned development of an offshore wind farm. Windfarm infrastructure  would restrict where new CO2 injection wells might be drilled and also affect and MMV strategy.
containment_summary: Leman Sandstone Formation is a mixed aeolian/fluvial succession with variable thickness (25 m–80 m) which is sealed by l Zechstein Group evaporites. The structure is defined to the south by a WNW-ESE-striking faults and in the by mostly dip closure. NW-SE-striking faults transect the field and segment the structure into several compartments. The Pickerill field has quite varying reservoir quality with the best reservoir quality found in the south-west.
assessment_notes: Storage volumes and site properties taken from source document which used a simulation to calculate volumes based on injecting 3-5 Mt per well. The site is compartmentalised: 16 MtCO2 within the Central compartment, 10 MtCO2 within the West compartment and 6 MtCO2 within the East compartment. The full amount for the site is given against the SRMS for mid case.
author: KE
source_of_analogue: Assumed to be based on remaining volume post depletion. Not stated in source

project_history: Amethyst is situated in license block CS017 which was awarded to Perenco on 01/8/23. The project planned is names Orion which aims to help decarbonise the Humber area> existing pipelines are planned to be reused.
development_plan: The project encompasses both the decommissioned Amethyst field and currently producing West Sole field, utilising depleted gas reservoirs, in which to permanently store captured CO2 within geological formations. Initial injection capacity of 1 Mpta rising to 6 Mtpa with injection commencing 2031 of 30 years.
containment_summary: None available
assessment_notes: The Orion project  is both the Amethyst and West Sole fields. Storage is volumetric and taken from the source document. Revised volumes likely in the future when as FEED and appraisal begin on the site. Initial capacity of 1 Mt and injection for 30 years is provided in the  source. This volume of 30 Mt is  placed as development pending. The full resource for Orion is cited as 126 Mt. The West Sole field has a reported capacity of 78Mt and hence the remaining volumes(126 - 78 - 30) = 17 Mt is addded to Amethyst as development unclarified dlack of development plan for those volumes yet.

containment_summary: The Viklau Fm sits on crystalline basement and is overlain by the Nar shale Mbr. It is  a mix of quartz sandstone and bioturbated sand and shale and was deposited in a near shore environment. It is an open aquifer that gently dips to the south-east. The sandstone may occur as lenses. Limited data exits to  characterise this site.
assessment_notes: The assessment is based on using the U.S.DOE storage efficiency factor 2% for formations. Effective capacity is stated as per source. Wells are not evenly distributed neither is it possible to define how many wells reach storage site depth. Source indicates only a few drill cores. Site is therefore classified as undiscovered.

publication: Mortensen, G.M., P.E.S. Bergmo and B.U. Emmel, 2016, Characterization and Estimation of CO2 Storage Capacity for the Most Prospective Aquifers in Sweden, 86, 352, 360
project_history: None Available
development_plan: No formal plan exists. However the dynamic simulations modelled injection based on six wells placed in the deepest part of the aquifer injecting 0.5Mt/yr in two wells and 1Mt/yr in 4 wells. Included in this were five water producer wells.
containment_summary: A clean carbonate quartz arenite with thin scattered layers of shale and siltone that is in an open/semi closed aquifer. Trapping is mainly stratigraphic and the entire formation has a wedge shaped depositions that gently dips towards the south east and pinches out in the north west. This formation continues towards Lithuania and Poland. The Aquifer is capped by a multi seal of a thick sequence of Ordovician carbonates and a thin layer of Alum Shale with variable continuity. The Ordovian sequences are capped further by a thick layer of Silurian Marlstone.
assessment_notes: The dynamic simulations of both 500Mt over 100 years and 250Mt over 50 years showed containment within the aquifer however the area of this study did not include the eastern and south-easternmost parts and the Dalders Structure so this study may result in less than the Volumetric method  based on the DOE storage efficiency factor for formations of 745 Mt cited in the NORDICCS CO2 Atlas . Limitations in the dynamic study are from data sparsity which may increase the uncertainties in capacity. Only two wells exist in this formation. An area of approx. 300Km2 is therefore classified as partly discovered. The remaining area is covered by the dynamic simulation and hence this site is partially discovered.  Note: The area of this dynamic simulation does not cover the full Faludden Formation aquifer and neither does the source state the areal extent of the simulation therefore it is not possible to subtract this from the full aquifer site. Hence the full aquifer will continue to have some capacity although it is  not possible to calculate  from the data available. A ball park figure would estimate that around 245Mt may remain outside of  the dynamic simulation area based on the volumetric calculation of 745Mt for the full Faludden aquifer from the NORDICCS Storage Atlas assessment. Due to the simulations and injection strategy  an SRMS of Prospect has been assigned.
author: KE
source_of_analogue: Dynamic Simulation that includes residual and dissolution trapping

publication: Mortensen, G.M., P.E.S. Bergmo and B.U. Emmel, 2016, Characterization and Estimation of CO2 Storage Capacity for the Most Prospective Aquifers in Sweden, 86, 352, 360
project_history: None Available
development_plan: No formal plan exists. However the dynamic simulations modelled injection based on four wells placed in the deepest part of the aquifer injecting 0.25Mt/yr in  and 1Mt/yr. Included in this were five water producer wells.
containment_summary: The Arnager Greensand was deposited in a marginal marine setting. It is an open and partly faulted aquifer with regional distribution and contains no traps or closures. The area suitable for CO2 storage is in the south-west from the Romeleasen Fault Zone. The seal is the Hollviken Formation comprised of a thick sequence of argillaceous limestone and chalk.
assessment_notes: The dynamic simulations in the source study, ran a maximum of  400Mt over 100 years with a rate of 1Mt/yr in each of the four wells. 14% of the CO2 migrated to depths less than 800M over a simulation of 6000 years.  Limited data reduces the accuracy of this study . There is some ambiguity over volumes from this source and the NORDICCS Atlas which also cites a modelled volume of 225 Mt.. Wells do exist on the site, and cover around 50%  and relatively evenly distributed. Neither is  possible to define how many wells penetrate the formations. 50% of The site is therefore classified as discovered due the dynamic simulation and well coverage and covered under  separate record. The remaining site (this record) remain partly discovered and classified at a sequence level.
author: KE
source_of_analogue: Dynamic Simulation that includes residual and dissolution trapping

publication: Anthonsen, K.L., P. Aagaard, P.E.S. Bergmo, M. Erlstrom, J.I. Fareide, S.R. Gislason, G.M. Mortensen and S.O. Snæbjörnsdóttir, 2013, CO2 Storage Potential in the Nordic Region, Energy Procedia, 37, 5080, 5092
project_history: None Available
containment_summary: Very limited data available. Source cites the occurrence of an anticline structure . The is an  reasonable layer of claystone on top of the Skagerrak Formation
assessment_notes: Very limited data available in the source document. Volumes likely to be based on the 2011 Geological Survey of Sweden.
author: KE
source_of_analogue: Theoretical volumes based on DOE for formations. 2% efficiency applied

publication: Stefatos, A., Giakoumatou, E., (eds), (2023), CARBON CAPTURE & STORAGE Regulatory Framework & Overall Structure, HEREMA S.A. Dimitriou Margari 18, 11525, Athens, Greece
project_history: The Prinos field has an active exploration license issued by HEREMA in 2022 to Energean for CO2 Storage. This includes the Prinos and Epsilon Fields and the underlying aquifer.  The project aims to contribute to local and regional decarbonisation with transport lines planned by both ship and pipeline.
development_plan: Internal and external studied have show the field can hold up to 3Mtpa of CO2 for 25 years. A phase 1 plan is to inject 1 Mt per year as compressed gas and then expand to liquid form by mid-2027. The second phase is to inject 3 Mt per year for 25 years.
containment_summary: The Prinos field and Aquifer are overlain by a thick sequence of evaporites, clastics and marls up to 2300m thick. Overall thickness of sediment in the basin is over 6km. The sites are in a fault controlled rift basin and characterised by high strike-slip faults. The overall basin appears tectonically stable although the Aegean region has more than 60% of European seismicity released in the area. The existence of the oil fields and fault bound trips indicates that the Prinos area experiences very limited seismicity.
assessment_notes: Extensive work has been conducted on the area by Energean but not available in the public domain. Storage  volumes are published by Energeia and HEREMA. Reservoir properties and geology is limited to a few papers in the public domain: Koukouzas, N.,  Ziogou, F. and Gemini, V.; (2009):  Preliminary assessment of CO2 geological storage opportunities in Greece, International Journal of Greenhouse Gas Control, Volume 3, Issue 4, 2009, Pages 502-513. Accurate well count is not available. The literature clearly reports the Prinos aquifer and Prinos depleted oil field separately in terms of capacity estimates.
author: KE

publication: Koukouzas, N., Tyrologou, P., Karapanos, D., Carneiro, J., Pereira, P., de Mesquita Lobo Veloso, F., Koutsovitis, P., Karkalis, C., Manoukian, E., Karametou, R., (2021), Carbon Capture, Utilisation and Storage As a Defence Tool Against Climate Change: Current Developments in West Macedonia (Greece). Energies, 14, 3321.
project_history: None Available
containment_summary: There is limited data available to understand the containment of this site. The Eptahori is overlain by the Pentaflos Fm and then a thick (1500m) layer of the Tsotyli and Ondria Fm. This is a molasse type basin that borders the Hellenic thrust belt. It has been classified as a cold basin with a geothermal gradient of 35 degrees C/km. There may be rollover anticlines that developed along the Theotokos thrust which can provide structural traps. In addition to this locations along the east margin of the trough and the Theotokos-Theopetra uplift  hold potential due to the potential for fault sealing along the structure. Between Krania and Theotokus uplift and erosion is likely to have removed the majority of the seal and hence the storage formation outcrops at surface.
assessment_notes: The initial assessment was based on a  static model project in 2016 by Tasianas, A. and  Koukouzas, N., (2016), ( CO2 Storage Capacity Estimate in the Lithology of the Mesohellenic Trough, Greece. Energy Procedia, Volume 86, 2016, 334-341). A later study by  Koukouzas, N., Tyrologou, P., Karapanos, D., Carneiro, J., Pereira, P., de Mesquita Lobo Veloso, F., Koutsovitis, P., Karkalis, C., Manoukian, E., Karametou, R., (2021),( Carbon Capture, Utilisation and Storage As a Defence Tool Against Climate Change: Current Developments in West Macedonia (Greece). Energies, 14, 3321) built on the 2016 study and refined the estimates based on the approach used by the DOE for formations and STRATEGY CCS project (Cavanagh, A.J, Wilkinson, M and Haszeldine, RS. 2020. Bridging the Gap, Storage Resource Assessment Methodologies, EU H2020 STRATEGY CCUS Project 837754, Report). The classification of storage resources via this approach first provided a qualitative assessment of suitability of the storge site quality and then provided a classification system based on a pyramid approach. It provided P10, P50 and P90 values to storage capacity
author: KE
source_of_analogue: Theoretical volumes based on DOE for formations. 1.5% efficiency applied

publication: Corless,V., Fjøsna, E., Havlik, J., Hoff, E., Taylor, D., Tjetland, G., and Vazaios,I., (2010) A bridge to a greener Greece A realistic assessment of CCS potential, The Bellona Foundation, Athens, Greece.
project_history: None Available
containment_summary: Storage potential exists in structures such as the Alexandria Anticline and the Loudias and Agriossykia Synclines. The faults near the border are complex and seismic activity in 1978 contributed to a reactivation of faults in the Mygdonian Basin. E-W striking faults are currently most active. These are significant considerations to take in to account for containment in this site. The seal is composed of Oligocene flysch with a thickness of around 1200m.
assessment_notes: There is limited data on this site. The source document provides geological characteristics and derive the capacity estimations from work done by the GeoCapacity project.
author: KE
source_of_analogue: EU GeoCapacity

publication: Corless,V., Fjøsna, E., Havlik, J., Hoff, E., Taylor, D., Tjetland, G., and Vazaios,I., (2010) A bridge to a greener Greece A realistic assessment of CCS potential, The Bellona Foundation, Athens, Greece.

project_history: None Available
containment_summary: The limestone reservoir, although extensive, is highly fractured. Suitable caprocks are the lignite formations (Ptolmain and Ardassa) and have a thickness of around 150-200m. This site is close to the Proastio-Komnina-Mesovouni fault zone which may impact the tectonic safety of the basin.
assessment_notes: There is limited data on this site. The source document  derive the capacity estimations from work done by the GeoCapacity project.
author: KE
source_of_analogue: EU GeoCapacity

publication: Welkenhuysen, K., Brüstle , A-K.,  Bottig, M., Andrea Ramírez, A., Swennen, R., 2 &  Piessens, K., (2016), A techno-economic approach for capacity assessment and ranking of potential options for geological storage of CO2 in Austria, Geologica Belgica, 19/3-4: 237-249
project_history: None Available
containment_summary: Due to a history of hydrocarbon production it is assumed that the containment is a limited risk with respect to trap and seal. The integrity of abandoned wells is not known and may be a leak risk.
assessment_notes: No CCS regulatory framework is in place as of Cycle 4, nor in the injection of CO2 for storage currently permitted - all sites considered Inaccessible. The assessment is based on a methodology for CO2 storage reservoir assessment, that uses the classification principle by Bachu et al. (2007). This methodology  enables making a realistic assessment of the practical and matched capacity in storage sites with large uncertainty ranges . It is based on the geo-economic evaluation of potential reservoirs with a calculation scheme called “PSS Explorer” as outlined in the source reference. , and a source-sink matching by a geo-techno-economic simulator called “PSS III”
author: KE
source_of_analogue: Match capacity estimate using a ranking criteria after Bachu et al.,  (2007)

publication: Veloso, F. M. L. 2021. Maturity level and confidence of storage capacities estimates in the promising regions. EU H2020 STRATEGY CCUS Project 837754, Report, pp 125.
project_history: None Available
containment_summary: This site is reported as having in the region of 120 wells drilled in its vicinity which has helped define the base of the aquifer. Porosity has also been evaluated from 21 wells in the western part by the source document. The site can be assumed relatively well discovered. It is capped by a regional and laterally continuous cap rock of the Graber Marl and Kloštar Ivanić marl
assessment_notes: The source reference used Geocapacity estimates and then applied a formular based on Carbon Storage Atlas -(USDOE, 2014) which integrated a 2% efficiency factor and other reservoir properties. This in-fact increased capacity estimates (251.6 Mt v 310 Mt). Despite 120 wells drilled in this region, it has not been possible to determine from the literature how many provide any data for the Poljana aquifer. This site is classified as undiscovered due to the great uncertainty surrounding data availability for such a large area.
author: KE
source_of_analogue: US DOE and efficiency factor fo 2%

publication: Veloso, F. M. L. 2021. Maturity level and confidence of storage capacities estimates in the promising regions. EU H2020 STRATEGY CCUS Project 837754, Report, pp 125.
project_history: None Available
containment_summary: This site is a daughter unit of Poljana. It is assumed to be capped by a similar regional and laterally continuous cap rock of the Graber Marl and Kloštar Ivanić marl. Porosities have been estimated from a porosity change with depth
assessment_notes: The source reference used Geocapacity estimates and then applied a formular based on Carbon Storage Atlas -(USDOE, 2014) which integrated a 2% efficiency factor and other reservoir properties. This in-fact increased capacity estimates (229 Mt v 269.7 Mt)

project_history: None Available
containment_summary: The Drava and Osijek situated in the Drava depression have very limited petrophysical properties. The lateral continuity of cap-rocks was assumed based on regional cross-sections. Cabuna Marl is primary seal in the western part of Drava depression and Borovo Marl in the eastern part. Seal thickness is based on data from 3 wells.
assessment_notes: The source reference used Geocapacity estimates and then applied a formular based on Carbon Storage Atlas -(USDOE, 2014) which integrated a 2% efficiency factor and other reservoir properties. This in-fact increased capacity estimates (1939 Mt v 3360.7 Mt)
author: KE

publication: Saftic, B., I.K. Mocilac, M. Cvetkovic, D. Vulin, J. Velic and B. Tomljenovic, 2019, Potential for the geological storage of CO2 in the Croatian part of the Adriatic offshore, Minerals, 9, 10
project_history: None Available
containment_summary: This area is a depression  that sites adjacent to the outcropping Dugo Otok Island. With in the basin  is a thick succession of marls and sands with and  large  undeformed structures. The proportion of permeable layers is less with an estimated net pay of 0.2. Tectonically this area is relatively  quiet, although seismicity does occur through Croatia so needs to be a consideration.
assessment_notes: Source reference used a theoretical approach to calculate capacity using a compressibility method defined by van der Meer & Egberts (2008) and a volumetric method by Goodman et al., (2011) which used the US DOE methodology. Wells do exist in this structure, however it is unclear if they  penetrate the formations or if they have data to characterise the site. The wells are not in the public domain to view. The Kate-1 well in close to the structure and may yield property values. The site is classified as undiscovered basin due to absence of defined units and limited information from any wells. However it is a large closed structure that could warrant further investigation.
author: KE
source_of_analogue: van der Meer & Egberts (2008) and USDOE

publication: Vulin, D., Vodopić, F., Arnaut, M., Saftić, B., Kolenković Močilac, I., Karasalihović Sedlar, D. and  Marko Cvetković, M.;(2021). Assessment of current state, past experiences and potential for CCS deployment in the CEE region: Croatia. BUILDING MOMENTUM FOR THE LONG-TERM CCS DEPLOYMENT IN THE CEE REGION project. https://ccs4cee.eu/assessment-of-current-state-ccs-4-cee/
project_history: CO2 EOR project underway by INA/MOL. The injection of CO2 in Ivanić oilfield started in October 2014 and northern part of Žutica oilfields in October 2016
development_plan: A pilot, full chain CCS project is currently being conducted at the Petrokemija ammonia production plant at Kutina. The project intends to capture, transport and inject 190.000 tonnes of CO2 per year. MOLgroup are the operator and plan are to inject in 2026. https://iogpeurope.org/wp-content/uploads/2023/10/Map-CO2-Storage-Projects-in-Europe.pdf
containment_summary: This is a producing field and assumed to be gas tight with respect to containment.
assessment_notes: Source reference used storage capacity estimates as reported in the EU GEOCAPACITY, 2009 AND STRATEGY CCUS, 2020 projects.

These fields are defined as small structural closures with numerous isolated sand bodies  in a progradational turbiditic sequence. Some of the fields may be too shallow (-500 to -1000m) for CO2 injection and data is not available to verify if this site is at the sufficient depth.

publication: Saftic, B., I.K. Mocilac, M. Cvetkovic, D. Vulin, J. Velic and B. Tomljenovic, 2019, Potential for the geological storage of CO2 in the Croatian part of the Adriatic offshore, Minerals, 9, 11
project_history: None Available
containment_summary: These anticlines are part of a carbonate complex. Structure 2  is a fault bound anticline that was active in the Pleistocene and Quaternary
assessment_notes: Source reference used a theoretical approach to calculate capacity using a compressibility method defined by van der meer & Egberts (2008) and a volumetric method by Goodman et al., (2011) which used the US DOE methodology.  Wells do exist close to this structure, however it is unclear if they  penetrate the formations or if they have data to characterise the site. The wells are not in the public domain to view.
author: KE
source_of_analogue: van der Meer & Egberts (2008) and USDOE

publication: Saftic, B.,  Bralic, N., ,Rukavina, D., Kolenkovic Mocilac, I., and Cvetkovic, M., 2024, Prospects for Geological Storage of CO2 in Carbonate Formations of the Adriatic Offshore, Minerals, 14, 409
project_history: None Available
containment_summary:
Late Eocene - Oligocene shales up to 1500m thick. Structural closure is defined by a. spill point at a depth of −2500 m. Structure is elongated in NW-SE direction with a length of 22 km
and a width of up to 4 km. limited faulting in the structure.
assessment_notes: Source reference used a theoretical approach to calculate capacity using a compressibility method defined by van der meer & Egberts (2008) and a volumetric method by Goodman et al., (2011) which used the US DOE methodology.  Wells were used to provide porosity and density data. Structure maps were used to define the volume and storage efficiency was based on the GeoCapacity approach.
author: KE
source_of_analogue: van der Meer & Egberts (2008) and USDOE

publication: Knopf, S. and F. May, 2017, Comparing Methods for the Estimation of CO2 Storage Capacity in Saline Aquifers in Germany: Regional Aquifer Based vs. Structural Trap Based Assessments, Energy Procedia, 114, 4710, 4721
project_history: None Available
containment_summary: Non available
assessment_notes: Knopf and May, (2017) assessed aquifers using a ‘regional aquifer based method’. This study built on results in previous studies by the   Storage Catalogue of Germany and GPDN using a volumetric approach but considered distinct reservoir- barrier units with capacity based on net thickness and porosity. They then ran Monte Carlo simulations with efficiency values between 0.9 and 4.6 to provide P10, P50 and P90 ranges. The study considered the capacity of structures within the units. This assessment has been favoured for the CRSC since it considers potential sites in Germany on a more containment basis (by considering both reservoir and barrier) and also refines the capacity estimates from previous studies. Despite the assessment reviewing 16 reservoir-barrier units and then subdividing them, the actual results for these are not reported. The reporting of the capacity by units is unclear and not well defined. In order to  maintain the capacity tied to distinct units/areas in Germany,  the breakdown of the results has been summarised to include The Bundastein (North German Basin), remaining units in the North German Basin and then the remaining units in all of Germany.
author: KE
source_of_analogue: Based on the Storage Catalogue of Germany and GPDN using a volumetric approach

site_name: Germany Depleted Oil and Gas Fields
publication: Anthonsen, K.L., and Christensen, N.P.,(2021),  EU Geological CO₂ storage summary, DANMARKS OG GRØNLANDS GEOLOGISKE UNDERSØGELSE RAPPORT 2021/34
project_history: None Available
containment_summary: Non available
assessment_notes: There is very little information surrounding the potential for storage in German’s oil and gas fields. CO2Stop assessed the potential via reporting saline aquifer locations  with hydrocarbon fields but and reported an overall capacity of 2Gt. Due to a significant absence of reporting and literature on German potential in depleted hydrocarbon fields an overall countrywide capacity is added to the CSRC of 2Gt. This is classified as inaccessible due to regulations. Location is reported for Germany only - no sites are specified.
author: KE
source_of_analogue: Uncertain due to very limited studieson potential in depleted hydrocarbon fields

publication: Beumelburg, C., 2023, Pioneering CCUS in Bulgaria: HeidelbergCement’s ANRAV project selected by EU Innovation Fund
project_history: Project ANARV - Project supported by EU innovation Fund.
development_plan:
ANRAV aims to develop the first full CCS _x000D_
value chain project in Bulgaria and in _x000D_
Eastern Europe. The objective is to capture _x000D_
the CO2 streams at the Devnya cement plant _x000D_
in Varna (HeidelbergCement group) and _x000D_
though an onshore and offshore pipeline _x000D_
system to store them in a depleted gas _x000D_
field in the Black Sea. Subject to regulatory _x000D_
and permitting aspects, the full-chain CCS _x000D_
project could be operational on 2028.
containment_summary: clay limestone as per CO2StoP Atlas
assessment_notes: This a depleted gas field. It was discovered in the Late Cretaceous / Late Paleocene calcarenite reservoir in 1993 by Texaco. Production ceased in 2015. It has been also considered as a gas storage site . The potential storage capacity of the Galata field after conversion is over to 2.0billion m3 (Levesley, G.; 2018) this is equivalent to a CO2 storage capacity in (STP) of  approximately 4 MT. This has been entered as a site despite the fact is below 10 MT storage capacity because there is a CCS project to develop the site for storage.
author: MP
source_of_analogue:
Volumetrc storage capacity was calculated using reservoir known properties and the gas extracted... The potential storage capacity of the Galata field after conversion is over to 2.0billion_x000D_
m3 (Levesley, G.; 2018)

project_history:
The University of Sofia proposes development of a CCS pilot project at the onshore saline aquifer of Pavlikeni with support of the EU_x000D_
capture projects. The project got cancel due to lack of budget.

assessment_notes: The University of Sofia proposed development of a project at the onshore saline aquifer of Pavlikeni. The site is close to Maritsa East power plants and which could provide a potential source of CO2. The depth to top of the storage FM is 800 -1400 m deep.

Assessment from  (Veloso, F. M. L. 2021. Maturity level and confidence of storage capacities estimates in the promising regions. EU H2020 STRATEGY CCUS Project 837754, Report, pp 125) gave an estimated capacity  of 56.81 Mt

publication: Veloso, F.M.L., I. Gravaud, F.A. Mathurin and S.B. Rhouma, 2022, Planning a notable CCS pilot-scale project: a case study in France, Paris Basin - Ile-de-France, Clean Technologies, 4, 2, 458, 476
project_history: None Available
development_plan: No development plan as per January 2024
containment_summary: The Dogger has been a key oi target since the 1950's and a main geothermal aquifer since the 1970's. The Dogger is overlain by Jurassic marls and in places Cretaceous and Tertiary sediments. The Dogger outcrops at surface in some  areas of the Paris on both the east and west side. Faults do exist through the formation.
assessment_notes: Storage first assessed during the Joule II Project  (1996), with a estimated capacity of 189 Mt (E=0.18%). The GeoCapacity project (2006-2009) provides the most confident estimate and used in this assessment. According to Brosse et al, (2010), Oil & Gas Science and Technology – Rev. IFP, Vol. 65 (2010), No. 3, pp. 375-403 the Dogger has a storage efficiency  of around 2%. This is based on 3D numerical modelling injecting 0.6 Mt CO2 over 4 years. The modelling was pilot scale only. Assessment by Bader et al  (2014) Energy Procedia 63 ( 2014 ) 2779 – 2788 did consider the Dogger for numerical  modelling to understand capacity, but was rejected due to risk of overpressure that would impact geothermal activity and high permeability. Veloso et al. estimates a small area of the Dogger around Grandpuis to have around 165 Mt CO2 based on theoretical capacity at  2% SE. The GeoCapacity estimates remain the most up to date capacity estimates at present for all the Dogger at a Basin scale, The smaller Veloso assessment is assigned to the sequence scale.
author: KE
source_of_analogue: GeoCapacity volumetric Calculation for basin. Effective capacity for sequence with 2% SE

publication: Bader, A.G., Thibeau, S., Vincké, O., Delprat Jannaud, F., Saysset, S., Joffre, G.H., Giger, F.M., David, M. Gimenez, M., Dieulin, A. & Copin, D. , 2014, CO2 storage capacity evaluation in deep saline aquifers for an industrial pilot selection. Methodology and results of the France Nord Project, Energy Procedia, 63, 2779, 2788
project_history: None Available
development_plan: No development plan as per January 2024
containment_summary: The site is faulted which could pose containment issues, however the formation is overlain by extensive marls through the basin.
assessment_notes: The GeoCapacity project (2006-2009) provided a value of 4311 for all the Keuper in the Paris Basin using an over estimated SE of 6%.  During the France Nord project the  Keuper was assessed on 2 sites: Keuper Nord and Keuper Sud along with the Buntsandstein over an area of 220,000 km2. Optimistic and pessimistic  cases were run with 15 injection wells.  The  results indicated a capacity of 140Mt in a homogenous reservoir and 40 Mt with heterogeneity. The results indicate that the high SE as reported in GESTCO and GeoCapacity do not apply and overpressure in the main issue with large injection volumes for saine aquifers.
author: KE
source_of_analogue: Dynamic simualtion. SE is 0.18% based on storage only in structural traps and only 3% of the aquifer pore volume is considered to be structural trap

publication: Bader, A.G., Thibeau, S., Vincké, O., Delprat Jannaud, F., Saysset, S., Joffre, G.H., Giger, F.M., David, M. project_history: None Available
development_plan: No development plan as per January 2024
containment_summary: There is risk of migration to the drinking water component of the aquifer. Injection to the west of the Marne Fault  may avoid this but the reservoir properties start to become less favourable and hence injection volumes are less on the west side.
assessment_notes: The GeoCapacity project (2006-2009) provided a value of 17640 for all the Bundsandstein in the Paris Basin using an over estimated SE of 6%.  During the France Nord project the  Keuper was assessed on 2 sites: Keuper Nord and Keuper Sud along with the Buntdsandstein over an area of 220,000 km2. Cases were run with 21 wells  and 23 wells to the east and wells of Faille de la Marne respectively.  The  results indicated a capacity of 157 Mt for  east and west of Faille de la Marne and 87 Mt for west of Faille de la Marne. The results indicate that the high SE as reported in GESTCO and GeoCapacity do not apply and overpressure in the main issue with large injection volumes for saine aquifers.
author: KE
source_of_analogue: Dynamic simualtion. SE is 0.18% based on storage only in structural traps and only 3% of the aquifer pore volume is considered to be structural trap

publication: Veloso, F.M.L., I. Gravaud, F.A. Mathurin and S.B. Rhouma, 2022, Planning a notable CCS pilot-scale project: a case study in France, Paris Basin - Ile-de-France, Clean Technologies, 4, 2, 458, 476
project_history: None Available
development_plan: No development plan as per January 2024
containment_summary: Data extracted from GeoCapacity / GETCO/ France North  projects and compiled in STRATEGY CCUS (2021)
assessment_notes: Storage first assessed during the Joule II Project  (1996), with a estimated capacity of 189 Mt (E=0.18%). The GeoCapacity project (2006-2009) provides the most confident estimate and used in this assessment. The value entered as a mean is using a efficiency of 6%. This is most probably a significant overestimation.
author: MP
source_of_analogue: GeoCapacity volumetric Calculation

publication: D. Pourtoy, A. Onaisi, M. Lescanne, S. Thibeau, C. Viaud. Seal Integrity of the Rousse depleted gas field impacted by CO2 injection (Lacq industrial CCS reference project France),  Energy Procedia 37 ( 2013 ) 5480 – 5493
project_history: The pilot project Lacq-Rousse took place from 2010-2013 injecting up to 51Kt of CO2.
development_plan:
This was a pilot project involving the capture of CO2 from a gas boiler at Lacq with  transport via a 27 km pipeline and storage
in the Rousse depleted gas field at a depth of 4.5 km
containment_summary: Upper Cretaceous seal units of Rousse Breccias, Calcareous turbidites and marly to siliciclastic turbiditic flysch. The Rousse reservoir is a compartmentalised horst structure.
assessment_notes:
Total operated Europe's first integrated industrial CO2 capture-transport-storage chain, with a pilot project involving the capture of CO2 from a gas boiler at Lacq and storage in the Rousse depleted gas field.  More than 51,000 tonnes of CO2 were successfully stored from
2010 to 2013.  The total site capacity is taken from the Joule II project. Only a fraction of the site capacity was used for injection. Full project details can also be sourced from : https://www.globalccsinstitute.com/archive/hub/publications/194253/carbon-capture-storage-lacq-pilot.pdf
author: KE
source_of_analogue: Oil & Gas replacement

publication: Holloway, Sam; Rochelle, Christopher; Bateman, Keith; Pearce, Jonathan; Baily, Heather; Metcalfe, Richard. 1996 The underground disposal of carbon dioxide : final report. Nottingham, UK, British Geological Survey, 355pp.
project_history: None Available
development_plan: No development plan as per January 2024
containment_summary: A limestone and dolomite reservoir with low porosity. As this is a producing gas field it is assumed containment will be sufficient for holding CO2.
assessment_notes: Data is taken from the Joule II project and hence likely out of date. However, there is an absence of data in the public domain for the Aquitaine fields. Project feasibility considerations for any Aquitaine field is that they are remote from major industrial areas. These fields also have low porosity values and may not be suitable  for supercritical CO2 injection. The source paper does not clearly indicate how capacity was calculated and does not state a voidage replacement assessment was used. Instead it states the capacity was estimated using a CO2 density of 700 kg/m3.
author: KE
source_of_analogue: Theoretical

publication: Geological Survey of Denmark and Greenland. (2014). Assessment of the CO2 storage potential in Europe. CO2StoP Final Report.
project_history: Italian first CCUS Hub, The capture CO2 at Ravenna will be injected in the depleted gas field Porto Corsini Mare Ovest
development_plan: The program entails a first phase (Phase 1) to create a capture and storage hub for 25 thousand tonnes of CO₂ per year, starting from 2024. Carbon dioxide will be captured by Eni’s natural gas treatment plant in Casalborsetti (Ravenna), conveyed toward the Porto Corsini Mare Ovest platform - which will be converted to this new use - and then injected into the Porto Corsini Mare Ovest depleted gas field.
assessment_notes: Development plan on place. ENI operator.
author: MP
source_of_analogue: Geocapacity 2009. Calculated using replacment volume

project_history: In the Po Valley, the Malossa reservoir was identified in the 70's. Assessed for the Geocapacity both together saline and Petroleum storage capacity (storage capacity varies in function of the efficiency factor0, the value enter is the E-2 %.
development_plan: No plan for CO2 storage, but assessed on 2012.
containment_summary: Caprock - Argile del Santerno (thickness 62- to 543m).
assessment_notes: The gas reservoir already used as gas storage  - 3D model built for the 3 reservoir units (saline and depleted reservoir) as part as a Horizon 2020 ENOS CLEANKER project. Storage capacity calculated for the  3 reservoir sections together
author: MP
source_of_analogue: Geocapacity 2009.

publication: Berta, M., C. Király, G. Falus, J. Gy and C. Szabó, 2011, Preliminary physical and geochemical study on a sedimentary rock series of the Pannonian Basin for CCS (Hungary), 4, 4719, 4723
containment_summary: The Szolnok Fm. is mainly formed by sandstone, its bottom is nearly 1000 to 3500 m deep under the surface, thus it would be used as a storage rock. Its cap rock (seal) is the Algyo Fm. with more than 1000 m thickness, and a clayey composition. System is not homogenous: there are siltstone beds both in the Algyo (clayey cover formation) and the Szolnok Formations (dominantly sandstone, turbidites). Siltstone in these formations does not have porosity high enough to be the storage rock, whereas the permeability is not low enough to be a good cap rock.
assessment_notes: Assessed as Sequence Play due to limited information beyond a geological sequence name.
author: BP
source_of_analogue: Unspecified

containment_summary: Volgian sandstone reservoir sealed by Cret. Claystones.
assessment_notes: Assessed as inaccessible due to Irish State law not permitting the geological storage of CO2
author: BP
source_of_analogue:
Based on volume replacement (Bachu & Shaw 2003) "principle that a variable proportion of the pore space occupied by the recoverable reserves will be available for CO2 storage, depending mainly on the reservoir drive mechanism" MCO2 = (VGAS (stp) / Bg). ??CO2 (Equation 1)
Where:
MCO2 = CO2 storage capacity (106 tonnes)
Stp = standard temperature and pressure
VGAS (stp) = volume of ultimately recoverable gas at stp (109 m3)
Bg = gas expansion factor (from reservoir conditions to stp)
??CO2 = density of CO2 at reservoir conditions (kg m-3)
The density of CO2 at reservoir conditions was calculated from an equation-of-state [5].

publication: geos.ed.ac.uk/sccs/project-info/2730, https://www.projectgreensand.com/en/hvad-er-project-greensand, https://carbonherald.com/denmark-awards-first-co2-storage-permit-for-the-project-greensand/
development_plan: Possibility of storing up to 1,5 million tonnes of CO2 per year in 2025/2026 and up to 8 million tonnes of CO2 per year in 2030
containment_summary: Nini-West Field. Palaeocene Marine sandstone's, Four-Way Dip closure.
assessment_notes: Assessed CAPACITY, Justified for development, injected 15 Mt as Pilot Project. No permits issued to continue injecting according to development plan as yet. Pilot Project - 4 months to inject 15 MT (Denmark has officially awarded its first CO2 storage permit for the offshore carbon capture and storage (CCS) Project Greensand. The permit was granted specifically to INEOS E&P and Wintershall Dea, two of the companies involved in the project, and allows a time- and quantity-limited injection of carbon dioxide. Namely, the injection and storage limit is set to 15,000 metric tons of CO2 over the coming four months, with an expiry date of April 1, 2023. The captured CO2 emissions are set to be injected deep underground, into the decommissioned Nini West oil field off the coast of Denmark.). Now seeking to ramp up to 8 MT/Year.

source_of_analogue: Unspecified

storage_unit_type: Open, no identified structural/ stratigraphic confinement
publication: Taragan, R. , 2018, Deep geological CO2 storage potential in the lower saline aquifer (Paleozoic - Triassic) in southern Israel, 1, 110
project_history: No project has been defined.
containment_summary: The "Lower Aquifer," A1, or "Permian Aquifer," is capped by the "Lower Aquitard." The Lower Aquitard comprises siltstones, shales, carbonates, and minor evaporites of the Triassic Ramon Gr. and the Jurassic Mishor Fm. Taragan (2018) determined the composite Permian Aquifer contains 3.3508 Gt of CO2 storage resources; however, when buffers are imposed on areas with less than 100 m of overlying seal or areas within 10 km of major faults, the CO2 storage resources decrease to only 1.53Gt.
assessment_notes: The authors evaluated four formations comprising the "Permian Aquifer" independently and then performed an evaluation on the aggregate of the four formations. Results reported here are for the individual formations and not for the aggregate. The aggregate "Permian Aquifer" evaluation is 3,350.8 Mt; however, when buffers are imposed on areas with less than 100 m of overlying seal or areas within 10 km of major faults, the CO2 storage resources decrease to only 1.53Gt.
author: JM

site_name: Negev Middle Aquifer Level I and II
storage_unit_type: Open, no identified structural/ stratigraphic confinement
publication: Calvo, R., & Gvirtzman, Z., 2013, Assessment of CO2 storage capacity in southern Israel, International Journal of Greenhouse Gas Control, 14, 25, 38
project_history: No project has been defined.
containment_summary: The "Middle Aquifer" is capped by the "Middle Aquitard." The Middle Aquitard is Late Jurassic and comprises shales with a few carbonate layers. Permeability ranges from 0.01 to 0.1 mD. Calvo and Gvirtzman (2013) excluded areas <800 depth, areas where seal (aquitard) is <100 m, and areas <10 km from fault traces or erosional formation outcrops.
assessment_notes: The authors also evaluate the "Lower Aquifer;" however, the evaluation was re-evaluated and updated by a more recent publication (Taragan, 2018). Portions of the Middle and Lower aquifer deeper than 2,500 m were assigned the label "Level II" in the resource estimate and are considered uneconomic by the authors.
author: JM

publication: Aktouf, A. and A. Bentellis, 2016, CO2-storage assessment and effective capacity in Algeria, 5, 1, 1038
containment_summary: The caprock has a minimum thickness of 200 m and is composed primarily of Silurian clay, which completely seals the potential reservoir.
assessment_notes:
Undiscovered saline formation.
Well: The study makes use of data from 200 wells located around the area. However, the location and if it penetrates the formation are unknown. Storage Efficiency: This initial assessment of the GSC capacity in Algerian deep saline aquifers encountered difficulties related to the storage efficiency factor, Esalin, and the potential storage capacity was calculated assuming that 0.54 or 5.4 % of the total pore volume could be filled or saturated (NETL 2010). The calculations provide a very conservative estimation of the effective capacity of the determined areas’ pro-sequestration of CO2 of approximately 1 GT or 5 Gt (Esalin = 1 and 5 %, respectively)
author: AH
source_of_analogue: Volumetric - from static model

publication: Aktouf, A. and A. Bentellis, 2016, CO2-storage assessment and effective capacity in Algeria, 5, 1, 1038
containment_summary: Containment: Coverage of these reservoirs is provided by Silurian clays, which are regionally well developed and provide a good coverage of the Cambro–Ordovician reservoirs. The base of these clays is highly radioactive with abnormally high pressures, increasing their coverage effectiveness. The Tournai reservoir sandstones are covered by Tournaisian and Namurian clays, and the Middle and Upper Devonian clays provide a caprock for the Gedinnian and Siegenien sandstones_x000D_

publication: Ringrose, P.S., A.S. Mathieson, I.W. Wright, F. Selama, O. Hansen, R. Bissell, N. Saoula and J. Midgley, 2013, The In Salah CO2 Storage Project: Lessons Learned and Knowledge Transfer, 37, 6226, 6236
project_history: In Salah project operational between 2004 and 2011 successfully stored 3.8 Mt CO2 in Krechba field. The CO2 is injected into the aquifer leg of a 20m thick carboniferous sandstone reservoir with no leakage of CO2 was reported during the lifetime of the project. The injection was halted due to potential geophysical risks, specifically reservoir fluid pressures
development_plan: The In Salah CCS project involves a total of three horizontal injection wells for storing carbon dioxide in Krechba field.
containment_summary: The containment of the Krechba field for the In Salah CCS project involves a Carboniferous saline seal, specifically consisting of 900 meters of Visean shale. This seal has successfully contained natural gas for approximately 200 million years, indicating its capability to securely store gases for extended periods.
assessment_notes: The In Salah CO2 Storage project has provided crucial insights into carbon storage processes, emphasizing the integration of monitoring into routine field operations and field development plans. The project highlighted the effectiveness of combining standard oilfield techniques with geotechnical and environmental monitoring practices, including the use of satellite InSAR data to understand geomechanical responses to CO2 injection. These methods, along with detailed reservoir and overburden data, are essential for assessing site-specific leakage risks and adapting operations as necessary. Additionally, managing legacy wellbore integrity and acquiring comprehensive baseline data are vital for ensuring the long-term integrity and understanding of CO2 plume behaviour within the storage reservoir.
author: AH
source_of_analogue: Simulation

publication: Saftic, B.,  Bralic, N., ,Rukavina, D., Kolenkovic Mocilac, I., and Cvetkovic, M., 2024, Prospects for Geological Storage of CO2 in Carbonate Formations of the Adriatic Offshore, Minerals, 14, 409
project_history: None Available
containment_summary:
Late Eocene - Oligocene shales up to 1500m thick. Structural closure is defined by a. spill point at a depth of −2500 m. Structure is elongated in NW-SE direction with a length of 22 km
and a width of up to 4 km. limited faulting in the structure.
assessment_notes: Source reference used a theoretical approach to calculate capacity using a compressibility method defined by van der meer & Egberts (2008) and a volumetric method by Goodman et al., (2011) which used the US DOE methodology.  Wells were used to provide porosity and density data. Structure maps were used to define the volume and storage efficiency was based on the GeoCapacity approach.
author: KE
source_of_analogue: van der Meer & Egberts (2008) and USDOE

formation: Unspecified: Eocene foraminiferal limestone and Upper Cretaceous rudist limestone
publication: Saftic, B.,  Bralic, N., ,Rukavina, D., Kolenkovic Mocilac, I., and Cvetkovic, M., 2024, Prospects for Geological Storage of CO2 in Carbonate Formations of the Adriatic Offshore, Minerals, 14, 409
project_history: None Available
containment_summary:
Late Eocene - Oligocene shales up to 1500m thick. Structural closure is defined by a. spill point at a depth of −2500 m.  The structure is elongated in the NW-SE direction with
a length of 11 km and width of up to 3 km
assessment_notes: Source reference used a theoretical approach to calculate capacity using a compressibility method defined by van der meer & Egberts (2008) and a volumetric method by Goodman et al., (2011) which used the US DOE methodology.  Wells were used to provide porosity and density data. Structure maps were used to define the volume and storage efficiency was based on the GeoCapacity approach.
author: KE

publication: Vandeweijer, V., Hofstee, C., Pelt, van, W., & Graven, H. (2020). CO2 injection at K12-B, the final story. SSRN Electronic Journal. https://doi.org/10.2139/ssrn.3820865
project_history: Demo project. Injection commenced 2004, halted 2017 when co2 separation at K12B field ceased.
containment_summary: Consist of several tilted fault blocks, no pressure communication between one another. Reservoir = Rotliegands sandstone (Permian). Top and Side seal = Zechstein salt, 500 m thick.
assessment_notes: Demo Project Assessed as stored as injection took place over 13 years. Potential for a further 25 Mt assessed as Development not viable, due to no ongoing appraisal at present time. 9 wells (K12-B1, K12-B2, K12-B3, K12-B3ST2, K12-B4, K12-B5, K12-B6, K12-B7, K12-B8ST). Injected  water leg after 2004. Prospect Area void from publication, preventing discovered vs undiscovered calculation to be performed.
author: BP
source_of_analogue: Unspecified

development_plan:
L10 area has been producing since 1975. Neptune Energy and its partners EBN Capital B.V., Rosewood 
Exploration Ltd. and ExxonMobil subsidiary XTO Netherlands Ltd. are progressing the studies required to 
submit a Storage Licence Application by Q1 2023. Feasibility study completed; targeting entry into FEED by YE 2022, FID by end of 2023 with first CO2 injection in 2026.
containment_summary: Not specified
assessment_notes: Assessed development on hold due to storage permit being issued and awaiting further information in the public domain concerning the projects progress.
author: BP
source_of_analogue: Unspecified

assessment_notes: Well numers are reported in CO2Stop, however, the distribution of the wells is not known, nor the formations they penetrate. The sites are not identified beyond thier basin location and no formations are listed. This site is therefore classed as an undicovered basin.
author: KE
source_of_analogue: CO2Stop

assessment_notes: Capacity is assessed from the methodology used in the GeoCapacity project. The resource here is the remaining Carpathian basin aquifer minus the values reported in CO2Stop. CO2Stop reported a more defined areas in the Carpathain basin, so to provide a complete perspective on the full aquifer resources in the Carpathians then the reamining Carpathain aquifer is reported as a seperate site.
author: KD
source_of_analogue: Geocapacity 2009. Calculated using replacment volume
